title: Prince Harry spends 8 000 edition Winnie Pooh book
story: Pictured: Prince Louis, photographed on April 24 leaving the hospital shortly after his arrival, will be christened in a private ceremony at St James' Palace today The flame-haired royal has splashed out £8,000 on a 1926 first edition version of the A.A. Milne book - of which 30,000 were printed in the first run, The Sun reports.           First edition: Uncle Prince Harry has splashed out on an £8,000 copy of Winnie The Pooh He is understood to have made the purchase from rare book seller Peter Harrington in Kensington, London.A friend told the newspaper: 'One of Harry's happiest childhood memories was being read a bedtime story by his mother.'She loved all the classics and Harry had the brilliant idea of starting a little library of first editions.'It is thought the newlywed originally considered buying Lewis Carroll's Through the Looking Glass, priced at £24,000 but decided Winnie the Pooh would be more suitable.The same friend told The Sun Prince Harry was a big fan of books as a youngster, devouring anything A.A. Milne but his favourite was Robinson Crusoe.           Family values: Prince Harry, pictured with his wife Meghan at a reception at Malborough House in London last week, is understood to be building a collection of first edition books for his niece and nephews It will be the first time the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their three children have been seen together as a family of five.Kensington Palace has yet to release the guest list, but royal christenings are usually a small, family affair.Newlyweds the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are likely to put in an appearance, as are Kate's pregnant sister Pippa Matthews, and her brother James Middleton.Meghan was christened and confirmed in the Chapel Royal by the Archbishop, who also married the Suits star and Harry at Windsor in May.    William and Kate revealed their newborn third child Louis to the world outside the Lindo Wing of St Mary's Hospital back in April following his birth  Prince George and Princess Charlotte were taken to meet their new brother by Prince WilliamDuke of Marlborough's younger brother marries his German...'Diana would be ashamed': Meghan's bitter half-sister...Share this article    How the families lined up at Princess Charlotte's christening in 2015      Prince Charles and Princess Diana with baby William for his christening in 1982Royal christenings are steeped in tradition, with customs passed down through the generations.When Prince Louis is baptised later today at the Chapel Royal, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are expected to keep to convention.Louis is expected to wear the royal christening robe - a replica of the original Honiton lace and satin robe made in 1841 for Queen Victoria's eldest daughter.The new robe was created by the Queen's dresser Angela Kelly.The original cream lace and white satin robe was last used in 2004 and is too delicate to be worn.According to tradition, the water used for Louis's christening will be holy water from the River Jordan, where it is said Jesus was baptised by John the Baptist.Louis will also be expected to be christened using the ornate silver gilt Lily Font - part of the Crown Jewels. title: Kate Archbishop Canterbury share joke sleeping Louis
story: The Duchess of Cambridge was greeted by Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, who baptised Kate and William's third child, as she headed into St James's Palace for the ceremonyThe Archbishop greeted the baby's grandfather, the Prince of Wales, and his wife Camilla as the royal family filed in to the palace. They were followed by Prince William, who was holding Prince Louis' brother George with his left hand and sister Charlotte with his right. Beaming Kate gazes lovingly at sleeping Prince Louis as she...Prince Harry spends £8,000 on first edition Winnie The Pooh...Share this articleWelby crouched down to speak to Charlotte, who gave the clergyman a very polite handshake, before turning his attention to Kate. The Duchess of Cambridge, wore a dress by her go-to designer Alexander McQueen for the occasion, looked overjoyed as she cradled Prince Louis and spoke to the Archbishop.           The Archbishop appeared to ask if Prince Louis was asleep when he spoke to the Duchess as the guests made their way to the Chapel Royal          Welby crouched down to speak to Charlotte, who gave the clergyman a very polite handshake, before turning his attention to KateJustin Welby had earlier expressed his joy at being asked to conduct the service.He said : 'I’m delighted and privileged to be christening Prince Louis today – a precious child made in God’s image, just as we all are. 'Please join me in praying for him and his family on this special day.'The baby prince – Louis Arthur Charles – was born in the private Lindo Wing of St Mary's Hospital in Paddington, London, on April 23 – St George's Day – weighing 8lb 7oz.He was welcomed into the Christian faith dressed in the same frilly, cream gown used for George and Charlotte.

title: Sleeping woman rudely awoken driver stops suddenly sending flying foot well
story: The woman is rudely awoken as she flies from her seat and into the seat well of a car in TaiwanThe video has been shared almost 10 million times, and has been issued to the public by Spanish police to encourage people to use seat belts.The video was first posted online by a Japanese user who said it originated in Taiwan.One social media user commented: 'I would be tempted to do that too if someone was sitting like that while I was driving.'Another added: 'I've been watching this on repeat and it makes me laugh every time!'

title: Wedding party goes wild Three Lions plays dance floor ahead England game
story: Heartwarming footage posted online shows crowds at a Sikh wedding dancing to the Skinner and Baddiel hit while chanting 'It's Coming Home' and waving glow sticks in the air  'Best wedding dance ever!' Fans cheered and chanted as they danced at the weddingKiran Dhaliwal, from London, posted the video with the caption: 'Sikh family wedding. I bloody love this country #ItsComingHome.'One guest at the wedding told MailOnline the bride and groom are 'avid football fans'.But as the wedding coincided with England's big clash against Sweden friends of the groom watched the match on iPads at their table.  Police identify woman pictured dancing on ambulance service...Share this article'Once England won they requested footballs coming home to be put on then it just erupted,' the guest said.Since being posted on Sunday the video has racked up nearly a million views and hundreds of responses.'Best wedding dance ever... whoever said that romance was dead was so wrong,' one person wrote.'What an absolutely beautiful moment, sending love and congratulations to the bride and groom,' they added.'A few in that video are defo on for Waistcoat Wednesday- we’re reclaiming the flag and the Waistcoat- you’re absolutely right - this is England- mad bonkers beautiful England,' another added, referencing the surge in waistcoat sales due to Gareth Southgate's trademark look.'Looks class,' one Twitter user said.'What a fantastic vid, looks amazing,' another added.          People on Twitter reacted to the video saying they loved it and '#ItsComingHome'It comes as a viral video from another wedding saw the groom's speech thanking 'Gareth Southgate and the England football team'.In the clip Verun Dewan looks to his bride Sarika Kapoor and asks: 'It's been four years, has it been four years?'He then adds: 'it's been an incredible journey, there's been ups, there's been downs, but today we've entered into a beautiful moment and I really look forward to the future we have together.'Can I ask you all to be upstanding and raise your glasses?'I really feel this is the start of something special and I cannot wait to see where it takes us next.'To Gareth Southgate and the England football team for reaching the World Cup semi-finals'.  So this happend at last night&#039s wedding....Posted by Farhan Zaheer on Sunday, 8 July 2018The guests then cheer as 'Three Lions' play.    The track, which is on track to top the UK singles chart this week, was written by The Lightning Seeds and comedians Frank Skinner and David Baddiel and originally released for the 1996 Euros. The song has taken a 30 percent lead over its nearest rival. George Ezra, who holds the current number one slot with his song Shotgun, has urged his fans to stream Three Lions and knock him off the top spot.

title: The Queen joined Harry Meghan royals arrive RAF service
story: Left to right: Prince Charles, Prince Andrew (behind), the Duchess of Cornwall, the Queen, the Duchess of Sussex, Prince Harry, Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge on the balcony of Buckingham Palace          Prince George, four, and Princess Charlotte, three, were allowed to watch the spectacle from a window of the palace          The Queen, dressed in blue in a nod to the RAF, applauded as the fly-past roared over Buckingham Palace          Vintage military aircraft perform a fly past over the Queen Victoria Memorial and Buckingham Palace          The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, who yesterday christened their son Louis, appeared in excellent spirits on the balcony          The Earl of Wessex, Countess of Wessex and the Princess Royal attend a reception at Horse Guards Parade, London, to mark the centenary of the Royal Air Force          Prince William, 36, right, shared a joke with his new sister-in-law the Duchess of Sussex, left, as they stood on the balcony          Prince Michael of Kent and Princess Michael of Kent attend a reception at Horse Guards Parade, London, to mark the centenary of the Royal Air Force       Look beautiful in blue like Kate in a coat dress by Alexander McQueenShop the current collection at NET-A-PORTERIt&#39s fair to say the Duchess of Cambridge has found a style that suits her and she&#39s sticking to it. The coat dress she&#39s wearing to mark the RAF centenary in London today might look familiar, and that&#39s because she&#39s worn versions of it in ivory and buttercup yellow to celebrate Princess Charlotte&#39s christening, as well as the Duke and Duchess of Sussex&#39s wedding earlier this year. It&#39s easy to see why she&#39s such a fan of this Alexander McQueen creation. The collarless style and statement fold-back lapels look very elegant when styled with swept-up hair, plus the cut of the coat dress is both classic and flattering. Of course it was custom made for Kate, but click (right) if your wardrobe is missing some McQueen. Or if you&#39re feeling inspired by the icy blue hue, check out the Duchess-inspired options we&#39ve rounded up for you in the edit below. From Zara to Suzannah, we&#39ve got all budgets covered!Harris Wharf London coat at The OutnetZara coat (now reduced to £29.99)Gina Bacconi jacquard coat at John Lewis (now reduced to £203)    Prince William appeared to tell a joke that had the whole Royal Family in stitches as they prepared for the fly-past          Senior royals took their lead from the Queen, centre, as she took in the action in the skies above Buckingham Palace          The Duchess of Sussex placed a reassuring hand on Harry's back as they left the balcony following the fly-past  After the fly-past the Duke and Duchess of Sussex joined royals at a reception in Buckingham Palace to mark the centenary          The Duke of Cambridge speaks to Jock Heatherill, 95, wing commander of 158th squadron, at the reception  Red, white and blue smoke streamed from the tails of the Red Arrows as they performed as part of the fly-past on Tuesday          A Second World War Lancaster bomber and Spitfires fly in formation above the crowds gathered in central London          The helicopters looked incredible as they flew in formation above the tens of thousands of people who gathered on the street          The Queen beamed with delight and the Royal Family looked enthralled as they took in the action in the skies  Meghan spent time chatting to Harry, left, and the Queen, right, with whom she enjoys a close relationship          The Duchess of Sussex burst into laughter as she shared a joke with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge on the balcony           The young royals could be seen leaning on the windowsill as they took a closer look at what was happening outside          Thousands of people packed the Mall to witness the incredible spectacle, while a further 2,200 people packed Westminster Abbey for the serviceEngland play Croatia in the World Cup semi-final on Wednesday. Mr Heatherill, who now lives near Rutland, joined the RAF in 1942. He served in a Halifax squadron that was part of bomber command which operated against German targets during the war.  The royals looked to the skies as aircraft roared overhead, including the RAF's new cutting-edge stealth fighter F-35 jets, in what was their first ever public appearance. The display also featured helicopters including the Puma, Chinook, Juno and Jupiter. The Royal Family looked enthralled as they took in the action in the skies.Up to 70,000 people line The Mall as ONE HUNDRED aircraft...The Fab Four on parade! Meghan and Kate compete in the style...Wrapped in the flag! Her Majesty, 92, struggles with the...Is this the 'Sussex sit'? Meghan commits ANOTHER 'royal faux...From Spitfire to stealth fighter: How Battle of Britain...The Duchess does Dior! Meghan stuns in black at Westminster...Share this articlePrince George, four, and Princess Charlotte, three, could be seen watching the spectacle from a palace window. It is the second time the Duchess of Sussex, 36, has appeared on the balcony at Buckingham Palace since the royal wedding in May, following Trooping the Colour. Meghan already appeared more comfortable with the high-profile nature of the appearance, confidently standing by her husband's side as they gazed to the sky.     The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were clearly in good spirits as they enjoyed the stunning fly-past          The Duchess of Cornwall, left, pointed out a point of interest to her mother-in-law the Queen during the fly-past          The Queen leaned in to apparently speak to the Duchess of Sussex as they took in the fly-past on Tuesday          The 'Fab Four' of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge squinted into the skies          The Royal Family looked resplendent on the balcony of the palace as 100 aircraft took to sky above the city          The Duchess of Sussex and the Duchess of Cambridge both flashed dazzling smiles as they turned their heads to the sky          The royals tilted their heads even higher as the incredible aeronautical display flew directly overheadMeanwhile the Duchess of Cambridge, 36, who yesterday attended the christening of her son, Prince Louis, took a break from her maternity leave to attend the event. Among the tens of thousands of spectators who lined the streets was Diana Terpougoff, who travelled from Malta to watch the flypast from The Mall.'I couldn't have felt more full of pride. What impressed me most was the pure skill on show, and of course the amazing 100 formation at the end,' she said.'Both my dad, and brother Tony were in the RAF for 25 years, so it makes this really special. It was worth the trip!'          Chinooks from RAF Odiham flew in the lead formation, along with Pumas from RAF Benson, for the RAF 100 fly-past          The Red Arrows, the Royal Air Force Aerobatic Team, delighted spectators as they roared over the London skyline          The Red Arrow display team created a stunning red, white and blue pattern with smoke from the tails of their aircraft          The Red Arrows brought their signature showstopping display to the fly-past, held to mark the RAF centenary  The Red Arrows created impressive patterns with the red, white and blue smoke as they zoomed over Buckingham Palace          Thousands of spectators turned out to watch the action - including these Typhoon aircraft flying in formation           The Red Arrows have been painted with a special 'RAF 100' logo to mark the milestone of the Royal Air Force this year          The military helicopters were among the 100 aircraft that took to the skies to mark the milestone for the RAFMalcolm Evans, from Birmingham, was in the RAF police between 1958 and 1968.He spent time in Hong Kong during his service and remembers it with great fondness.'It brought tears to my eyes to see those planes go through the sky. I'm so pleased we're still able to put that many planes in the air,' he said after watching from The Mall.The crowd in The Mall watched agog as first the helicopters, then the light aircraft, the transport planes and finally the Red Arrows flew over.Groups of school children stood open mouthed while visitors munched happily on their picnics and Champagne corks popped.          The Duke and Duchess of Sussex looked lovingly into each other's eyes as they attended the reception          The Duchess of Sussex charmed guests as she joined her new husband Prince Harry at the reception          Prince William looked delighted as he spoke to 95-year-old Jock Heatherill, wing commander of 158th squadron, Halifax's          The Duchess of Cornwall, 70, sipped on what appeared to be a glass of wine as she mingled with guests at the reception           Prince Charles holds court as he speaks to young members of the Royal Air Force at a Buckingham Palace reception           Prince Charles, who attended the event in military uniform, looked in excellent spirits as he spoke to guests          The Duchess of Sussex donned a black fit-and-flare dress for the occasion, one of her most high-profile as a royalAfter the red, white and blue Red Arrows display, the crowd erupted into applause as the Queen looked on from the balcony at Buckingham Palace.Prior to the fly-past, the royals watched as the Queen and Prince Charles presented a new Queen's Colour to the RAF in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace. The monarch also made a brief speech praising the 'tenacity, skill and gallantry' of the RAF. She said: 'Presenting the Royal Air Force with a New Queen's Colour provides an opportunity to congratulate the Service for your remarkable contribution to Defence over the last hundred years.'Tenacity, skill and gallantry have been your hallmarks, as you have helped to safeguard freedom and security in many parts of the world. I remember the Battle of Britain being fought in the skies above us, and we shall never forget the courage and sacrifice of that time.          The 'Fab Four' of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (left) and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex made a joint appearance          The animated young royals were a picture to behold as they donned their finery - including Harry in his military uniform - for the event          Prior to the fly-past, the royals watched as the Queen and Prince Charles presented a new Queen's Colour to the RAF in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace          The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge appeared in particularly good spirits and could be seen sharing a joke together           The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex watched the presentation today    The Queen was joined by her son Prince Charles as she presented a new Queen's Colour to the RAF to mark its centenary          In the forecourt of Buckingham Palace, RAF personnel arranged themselves to form the slogan 'RAF 100'          Thousands of spectators lined the Mall to watch uniformed members of the RAF parade past, pictured           Crowds of people watch on as the Queen's Colour is presented to the Air Force by Her Majesty in the Buckingham Palace forecourt this afternoon          Thousands are expected to line the streets to catch a glimpse of the iconic fly-past, while more than a thousand servicemen and women took part in a parade on The Mall (pictured)          Members of the Royal Air Force parade down The Mall, London after a service at Westminster Abbey, to mark the centenary of the Royal Air Force          Police estimate between 65,000 and 70,000 people lined the streets to watch the fly-past today. Pictured, the Mall          An RAF band led the procession as they made their way down the Mall, which was hung with Union and RAF flags          Uniformed servicemen and women march down the Mall as thousands turn out to pay tribute to the RAF on its centenaryThousands are expected to line the streets to catch a glimpse of the iconic fly-past, while more than a thousand servicemen and women took part in a parade on The Mall.William and Kate arrived at the Abbey this morning less than 24 hours after Prince Louis' christening at St James's Palace, attended by Harry, Meghan, Charles, Camilla and the Middletons.But the Queen and Prince Philip were not there because of a busy week for the 92-year-old monarch, including Trump's three-day visit to the UK from Thursday           The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex arrive at a service at Westminster Abbey today          Queen Elizabeth II attends a service at Westminster Abbey, London, to mark the centenary of the Royal Air Force today    Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex leave the service at Westminster Abbey this morning          William and Kate shared a light-hearted moment with their new sister-in-law the Duchess of Sussex outside the service           The Duchess of Sussex held her husband's arm while the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge walked separately into the Abbey  Prince Charles, right, and the Duchess of Cornwall, left, will take part in a number of commemorative events today          The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex arrived as a foursome for the service          Prince William, 36, took a moment to admire the beauty of Westminster Abbey as he took his seat next to Kate. Pictured behind, left-right: the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Prince Andrew, Prince Edward and the Countess of Wessex, Princess Anne, Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence           The Queen, 92, arrived for the service as she kicked off a busy day of engagements commemorating the RAF centenary          The Queen was at Westminster Abbey this morning as the royals helped kick off a momentous day-long celebration to mark 100 years of the Royal Air Force          Meghan and Harry were all smiles as they took their seats in Westminster Abbey with a host of royals and RAF officials          The Duchess of Cambridge, 36, looked elegant in a mint-coloured coat and matching hat for the occasionMore than 2,200 people packed Westminster Abbey for the service, with dignitaries including Prime Minister Theresa May, Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn attending.The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, addressed the congregation and said the RAF has in its first 100 years been a decisive factor in serving the country, as well as being key in protecting democracy and freedom.With an RAF ensign draped over the high altar behind him in the abbey, Mr Welby also highlighted how members of his own family have served and been killed in the RAF - drawing attention to his own father who flew low level sorties in Burma.   The Queen looked resplendent in a iridescent purple and teal coat, which she wore over a dress of similar colours          Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall accompanied the Queen into Westminster Abbey on Tuesday  The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, left, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, right, arrived at Westminster Abbey together          Prince Charles donned his military uniform for the service at Westminster Abbey, which was attended by servicemenThe Queen, left, looked delighted to be joined at the service by her grandson Prince Harry, right, and his wife Meghan  The Duchess of Sussex opted for an ultra-feminine black dress with a full skirt as she joined her husband Prince Harry          Prominent members of the royal family have arrived at Westminster Abbey as part of a day-long celebration of the Royal Air Force as it celebrates its centenary year      Prince Harry, Meghan and Prince William are among the royals who have arrived at Westminster Abbey for a service to mark the RAF centenary  Royals including Prince Edward, left, and Prince Michael of Kent, right, donned their military uniform           The Queen was joined by family members including the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke of Cambridge and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex          The Duchess of Cornwall was the picture of elegance in a white dress, pearl necklace and a cream hat for the occasion           Princess Anne and her husband Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence arrived for the RAF centenary service on Tuesday          The Duke of Sussex gallantly took his wife's arm as they arrived for the service at Westminster Abbey on Tuesday      The Duchess of Cambridge, who yesterday attended her son Prince Louis' christening, sported a large diamond broochFrom then on each year one male member of the cadets would be awarded with the sword and a female with the sash and brooch with the selection based on their all-round performance throughout the year.This tradition took place until last year when it was decided that the girls should receive the Dacre sword like their male counterparts. Ms Conder who was the best female cadet in 2015 told the Telegraph: 'It is quite an honour (to wear the brooch). I was the last cadet to wear it, and now she is wearing it. It is the best accesory.'Although the Duchess is not a cadet they seem to think she was deserving of the brooch. A spokesperson from Buckingham Palace says that the cadets presented the brooch to the Duchess as a gift following her appointment as Honorary Air Commandant of the organisation.Source: Royal Air Force Air Cadets          When it came to her ensemble the mother-of-three proved that if it ain't broke don't fix it as she wore the same Alexander McQueen coat worn to Prince Harry and Meghan's wedding but in a pale blue                                                    Just 15 years after the first-ever powered flight undertaken by the Wright brothers, the decision to create the RAF was made after the War Cabinet inquiry criticised the poor organisation of Britain's air forces.  The officer commanding the Red Arrows, Wing Commander Andrew Keith, who took the helm in August, said it is an incredible year to be leading them.'We will put the red, white and blue on at the end of the flypast, which I think is a fitting way to end it, which is great,' he said.During the flypast, he said he will be flying in the formation in the back seat of the team leader's jet, 'getting a few photos'.'It is going to be business as usual for us - and hopefully clocking over that 100th aircraft,' he said when asked if they will be doing anything different on the day.  Sophie, Countess of Wessex, left, and the Duchess of Cambridge, right, both opted for dresses in soft colours          Prince Harry shared a joke with his uncle Prince Andrew, who was seated on the other side of the Duchess of Sussex           The newlyweds, who tied the knot in May, looked in excellent spirits as they took their seats ahead of the service          The Queen was greeted as she arrived at Westminster Abbey ahead of the commemorative service on Tuesday          Prime Minister Theresa May was among those who spoke at the service. She wore an RAF pin on her lapel           Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, pictured, and Prime Minister Theresa May were also invited to attend  From Spitfire to stealth fighter: How Battle of Britain planes and cutting-edge new jets were among 100 aircraft thundering across skies for RAF centenary The largest concentration of military aircraft in recent memory formed in the skies above London today as the Royal Air Force marks its centenary year.Up to 100 jets, helicopters and aeroplanes from across a range of different eras of RAF history, including Spitfires and modern state-of-the-art aircraft, took part.The RAF's new cutting-edge stealth fighter F-35 jets featured, as well as helicopters including the Puma, Chinook, Juno and Jupiter.Aircraft from the Battle of Britain Memorial Flight including the Dakota, Lancaster, Hurricane and Spitfire were also part of the line-up, as are training aircraft including the Prefect, Tucano and Hawk.  Today's flypast began over Suffolk to the west of Ipswich at around 12.45pm before heading towards Colchester, and then Chelmsford.The formation continued over the M25, Stapleford Abbotts, Hainault Forest and on to central London – passing the Olympic Park, Hackney, Bethnal Green and Shoreditch before getting to The Mall at around 1pm.          The historic flypast began over Ipswich at 12.45pm, with crowds able to watch it fly over Essex and into London, before different aircraft headed off in separate directions towards RAF bases          Up to 100 jets, helicopters and aeroplanes from across a range of different eras of RAF history, including Spitfires and modern state-of-the-art aircraft, took part in today's centenary celebrations          Today's flypast began over Suffolk to the west of Ipswich at around 12.45pm before heading towards Colchester, and then Chelmsford  Puma HC2 - The four-bladed, twin-engined utility unit is the RAF's medium-sized transport helicopter and is used a variety of combat roles, including the tactical movement of troops, weapons, ammunition and stores on the battlefield.Chinook HC4 - An extremely  versatile heavy-duty helicopter that can be operated from land or sea bases into a range of erse environments, from the Arctic to the desert or jungle. Chinooks are primarily used for trooping, resupply and battlefield casualty evacuation.Juno H135 - The RAF's basic helicopter unit that has now replaced the Squirrel. It is currently the quietest in its class.Jupiter H145 - A training helicopter that has replaced the Bell Griffin. The state-of-the-art cockpit includes the very latest in Airbus Helicopters avionics.            The RAF's Puma unit (shown left) and the Chinook (right) will both feature in today's flypast. Both units are used mainly for transportation, resupply and evacuation            With its mix of weapons the Tornado GR4 is capable of engaging all targets on the modern battlefield. It is the UK's primary ground attack platform and also fulfils an important reconnaissance roleDakota - The Douglas C-47 Dakota is among the most successful aircraft designs in history. It became one of the world's most famous military transport aircraft and saw widespread use by the Allies during World War Two and to this day is still used by military air forces and civilian operators worldwide.Lancaster - The Avro Lancaster is the most famous and successful RAF heavy bomber of World War Two. The prototype Lancaster took to the air for its first flight from Ringway, Manchester, on 9 January, 1941. It carried out several daring and famous missions, including the legendary Dambusters raid. Spitfire - Perhaps the most iconic fighter plane to ever fly in the RAF, the Spitfire is synonymous with World War Two and the Battle of Britain. Produced in greater numbers than any other British combat aircraft before or since the War, 20,341 Spitfires were built in 22 different variants and the aircraft remained in production for 12 years. Hurricane - The sister unit to the Spitfire, the Hawker Hurricane is one of the classic fighters of all time. It was at the forefront of Britain's defence in 1940 and it played a major part in achieving the victory of 1945. Sadly, there are only 12 Hurricanes still airworthy worldwide only 6 of those in UK.Prefect T1 - A nimble two-seated training and aerobatic low-wing aircraft, the Grob 120TP Prefect is set to replace the Tutor T1 in the elementary flying training role with 57 Squadron at RAF College Cranwell.            Both the much-regarded Typhoon (shown left) and the legendary Spitfire (right) will take part in today's flypast over Buckingham Palace            The Spitfire, Hurricane, Lancaster and Dakota will all join in during the flypast of part of the Battle of Britain Memorial FlightTucano T1 - The Tucano is a turbo prop which provides basic fast jet training to RAF and RN aircrew on their training pathway to frontline fast jet aircraft. It is flown by 72 Squadron with No. 1 Flying Training School at Royal Air Force Linton-on-Ouse.Shadow R1 - One of the UK's key intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance planes, the Shadow has electro-optical and electronic capabilities while it is also fitted with a comprehensive defensive aids suite.Hercules C-130J - The Hercules is the RAF's primary tactical transport aircraft and has been the backbone of UK operational  tasks since it was brought into service in 1999. It is frequently employed to operate into countries or regions where there is a threat to aircraft.A400M Atlas - A large transport unit, the Atlas provides tactical airlift and strategic oversize lift capabilities complementing those of the Hercules and C-17 fleets. It has the ability to carry a 37-tonne payload and can fly at altitudes up to 40,000ft.C-17 Globemaster - The RAF's largest transporter, the unit is used for combat, peacekeeping or humanitarian missions worldwide. C-17 is capable of rapid, strategic delivery of troops and all types of cargo to main operating bases anywhere in the world. It can transport 100,000lb of freight  while flying at altitudes above 35,000ft.            The RAF's largest transporter, the Globemaster (pictured) is used for combat, peacekeeping or humanitarian missions worldwide and will be the biggest aircraft on show today            A surveillance unit, the Sentinel provides long-range, wide-area battlefield surveillance, delivering critical intelligence and target tracking information to British and coalition forces. The aircraft is currently deployed in Iraq and SyriaBAE146 - The transporter's primary role is the transport of senior government ministers and Ministry of Defence  personnel and, most famously, senior members of the royal family.Sentinel - A surveillance unit, the Sentinel provides long-range, wide-area battlefield surveillance, delivering critical intelligence and target tracking information to British and coalition forces. The aircraft is currently deployed  in Iraq and Syria.Voyager - This behemoth is the RAF's sole air-to-air refuelling tanker and also operates as a strategic air transport. As well as providing fuel in the air, it can operate as a passenger aircraft in much the same way as a civilian airliner.Rivet Joint RC-235w - RC-135W Rivet Joint is a dedicated electronic surveillance aircraft that can be employed in all theatres on strategic and tactical missions. Its sensors 'soak up' electronic emissions from communications, radar and other systems.E-3D Sentry - This surveillance unit  is an airborne early warning and command and control aircraft. The Sentry monitors airspace to provide threat detection of enemy aircraft and has the capability to detect ships, relaying information to maritime aircraft.Hawk T1 - The Hawk Mk1 is a fully aerobatic, low-wing, transonic, two-seat training aircraft that is still used in a number of roles for the RAF.            The RAF's brand new fighter jet, the F-35 Lightning, is a state-of-the-art combat unit. Capable of flying at a top speed of 1,200mph and avoiding detection from enemy radars, it can operate from an altitude of 50,000ftHawk T2 - An update on the T1, the later model includes a glass cockpit and comprehensive avionics suite which provide a realistic advanced fast jet environment for training pilots.Tornado GR4 - With its mix of weapons the Tornado GR4 is capable of engaging all targets on the modern battlefield. It is the UK's primary ground attack platform and also fulfils an important reconnaissance role.Typhoon FGR4 - An extremely agile, multi-role combat aircraft used in all the RAF's current operations. It is deployed for the full spectrum of air operations, including air policing, peace support and high-intensity conflict.Red Arrow - The RAF's Aerobatic Team, the Red Arrows, is one of the world's premier aerobatic display teams. Representing the speed, agility and precision of the RAF, the team is the public face of the service. They assist in recruiting to the Armed Forces and act as ambassadors for the United Kingdom at home and overseas.F-35 Lightning - The RAF's brand new fighter jet is a state-of-the-art combat unit. title: Chinese man arm stuck squat toilet entire night trying reach dropped keys
story: A man in central China spent an entire night with his arm stuck in a squat toilet after trying to reach for keys. He called for help for six hours until a neighbour heard him in the morning          A firefighter was seen breaking the porcelain toilet with a large hammer on Sunday morningChinese knife man is sentenced to death after stabbing a...Ouch! Monkey punches curious young girl in the face after...Is this the most scenic highway you've seen? Incredible...Fancy dinner with a view? Daredevil tourists enjoy a luxury...Share this articleVideo footage of the rescue operation in Hubei province shows the man's right arm completely jammed down the toilet. The man, identified as Mr Wang, was seen lying flat on his front, unable to move. He had accidentally dropped his keys in the toilet at about 11pm the night before and attempted to reach for them, but could not get his arm out due to the high pressure inside the tube.          He attempted to reach for his dropped keys, but could not get his arm out due to the high pressure inside the tube. Firefighters spent 30 minutes to free him          The man, identified as Mr Wang, was seen lying flat on his front, unable to moveA firefighter was seen breaking the porcelain with a large hammer and a drill.'Your arm is stuck inside the pipes, yes?' another fireman asked Mr Wang.'Yes - for the whole night,' he replied. 'Can you still feel your arm?''Yes,' he said.After 30 minutes, firefighters freed the man. His arm was red and swollen, according to the report. He was taken to hospital for a checkup.           After 30 minutes, firefighters freed the man. His arm was red and swollen          After being rescued, the man was taken to hospital for a checkupSquat toilets seem to pose a safety hazard in China - getting a body part stuck in the toilet is apparently a common occurrence. A man in south-east China also had his entire arm stuck in a squat toilet when he tried to retrieve his phone in May.Firefighters had to use washing-up liquid to reduce the friction while breaking the porcelain toilet to free the man's arm.In April, a woman got her foot stuck inside a squat toilet after using a public bathroom in Nanning. Firefighters had to use cooking oil to ease her leg out of the contraption.

title: Couple buy favourite beach 250 000
story: Mother-of-six Stephanie Roach and husband Dan have spent every summer holiday at Saundersfoot, west Wales, and have now bought it          The 2.2 acre stretch of golden sands in  Pembrokeshire was put on the market for £250,000The 2.2 acre sandy beach just three miles from the tourist hotspot of Tenby is popular with tourists due to its blue flag status.Adult literacy teacher Stephanie - known as Stevie - said they decided to buy the beach after it went up for sale because they feared it may fall into the wrong hands.She said: 'Our biggest fear was somebody might buy the beach and do something against the ethos of it.'We wanted to preserve the beach as it is and for it to remain family friendly.Gabriel Jesus, Gylfi Sigurdsson, Nemanja Matic and fellow...Inside John and Toni Terry's lavish Surrey mansion: A...Film producer and New York Giants chairman Steve Tisch...Share this article'We'd heard about the sale and I said 'oh gosh, surely other people feel like us, can't we get a group of like-minded people together?''So Dan phoned up and knocked on people's doors and within moments there were five of us.'I've been brought up round here, as has my husband and his brothers and the neighbours who've also come into the consortium.'          Mr Roach first went to Saundersfoot aged two and has been every year since, making new memories with his wife Stephanie (pictured together at the beach) and their six children The couple - who live in Cambrrideshire but have a holiday home in Saundersfoot - joined together with three friends to form a consortium to buy the beach.          Adrian and Nicola Alford (pictured on the sands) decided to sell the plot of land after 10 yearsIt owns the trading rights to the beach and has so far struck deals with two vendors to trade on the beach - a local ice cream van and a stall selling fresh local seafood.But the couple who paid an undisclosed sum for the beach want to protect it rather than exploit the natural beauty.Stevie said: 'We wanted to promote the local businesses that are important to the community.'It's a very vibrant community here, and people look after the beach, and that's what we really want to preserve and enhance.' Previous owners Adrian and Nicola Alford decided to sell the plot of land after 10 years because they wanted to pursue other interests.Adrian, 53, ran the beach for 10 years with his wife Nicola, 51, and son Toby, 29.Estate agents RK Lucas &amp Son say Saundersfoot is one of the most visited tourist destinations in west Wales.          The Pembrokeshire beach, often packed in good weather, has been secured for future generationsAdrian said: 'We cater for families wanting a seaside experience. We sell ice-cream and hot and cold food, run a bouncy castle and rent out sun loungers and deck chairs as well as kayaks, pedalos and stand-up paddle boards.'It is such a beautiful place to work, absolutely stunning. We get beautiful sunrises.'You come down first thing in the morning when there is hardly a soul around and then the crowds slowly build up.'It will be nice to see another couple take it on with the energy and vitality it needs.'

title: Eagle eyed photographer captures big cat hiding amid foliage Kenya it
story: The leopard is one of the world's largest cats, but it is surprisingly difficult to pick out the deadly predator in this photo as it has blended in perfectly with its surroundings          Leopards are covered in a coat of spots which helps to break up the animal's outline and helps it to blend in with the foliage and grasses that it uses for cover while huntingWARNING: Answer below While taking a tour of the reserve Gerlach, who has been photographing animals for more than 40 years, managed to discern the deadly predator despite its best efforts at hiding itself.  Leopards are found across Kenya and, while their numbers have fluctuated in recent years, are not as threatened by poaching or habitat destruction as their relatives such as lions.Despite adults weighing up to 100lbs, leopards are actually the smallest of the big cat species, and most of their hunting tactics are designed to keep them out of the way of their larger cousins.Ouch! Monkey punches curious young girl in the face after...Arachnophobes, look away now! The terrifying moment a giant...Feline intuition: Cats at daycare center run for cover...Share this articleLeopards are solitary animals, unlike lions, and largely hunt at night to avoid competition with the so-called King of the Jungle.Because of their small size they will often drag their quarry up a tree to prevent it being stolen by other predators, which offers a clue as to where this leopard is hiding.They are similar in appearance to jaguars, but are smaller and less muscular. They also lack a dot in the centre of their spots, which is the mark of a jaguar.           The leopard is lazing in the branches of this tree, which is one of the animal's favoured hang-outs, as it keeps it out of the way of much larger predators that patrol the ground below          Even standing up in the tree, the leopard is hard to see (centre). The cats will often drag their prey into trees to stop it being stolen by lions and other large predators          Leopards are relatively common across Kenya but particular concentrations can be found inside the Maasai Mara and Samburu National ReservesIt is unlikely that the two species would be confused in the wild, however, as they do not share a habitat.Leopards live mostly across southern parts of Africa and in scattered communities across Asia, Pakistan and Malaysia, while jaguars live in the Americas.Leopards can be spotted across Kenya but there are particular concentrations in the Maasai Mara and Samburu National Reserves.As with many of Africa's largest predators, their numbers increase dramatically around wildebeest migration season as they follow the herd, hoping to pick off stragglers.Igor Gerlach has been a photographer since 1974 and began taking pictures of wildlife in 1976. He has since won dozens of awards and published hundreds of images, both in books and national newspapers.

title: Lycra clad lout ploughs little girl bike
story: Footage shows the impatient cyclist speeding past a family as they rode past an antiques shop          As the cyclist tries to weave past them, he collides with the youngster's bike, sending her tumbling to the groundThe hit-and-run incident was captured on security cameras outside Grandad's Attic antiques shop in Stourbridge, Worcestershire, on Sunday  at 1pm.Shop owner Dave Powell, 57, said: 'I was inside my shop and I heard some kind of thing going on and a girl crying.Apartment which serves up smashing views of Wimbledon's...The tragedy behind the man who wants to break England¿s...Poundworld will close 25 stores causing the loss of 242 jobs...Number of prisoners using Facebook, YouTube and Instagram...Share this article'I looked out my door, and presumed she had fallen off her bike but then saw her dad come running back towards her and realised that she had been knocked off the bike by an adult.'Her dad had chased after him but then come back to see how his daughter was. He was torn between going after the cyclist and seeing how his daughter was.          The rider then cycles off leaving the girl in tears on the road before her horrified father rushes to comfort her          The hit-and-run incident was captured on security cameras outside Grandad's Attic antiques shop in Stourbridge, Worcestershire          The youngster's father can be seen trying to comfort her as the cyclist flees the scene'There was a group of people gathered. I gave her a drink and a bowl of water and we mopped her wounds. They were just grazes but she was very upset.'There is a bridge and by the side of the bridge there is a little wall, 18 inches high, and mountain bikers think it is clever to hop up onto the wall and hop off the other end.'The family were walking along the wall and as they got to the end he was jumping off. He jumped right into the little girl.'I think part of the problem is that it has got so popular. There are more people cycling on the footpath.'Mr Powell said he understood the family had reported the incident to West Mercia Police.

title: Rare collection set fetch 2 000 auction
story: Pictured: The late John Entwistle – who performed bass, backing and lead vocals from 1964–2002 - pictured with a friend at Charing Cross on May 13, 1966           Signed! Roger Daltrey scrawled his signature on this candid shot of him wearing a floral shirt and on-trend glasses near Charing Cross on May 13, 1966           Fan turned friend: Gaby McGee, pictured right with Roger outside Heathrow in 1967, was a huge supporter of the band but later became pals with them   Rare: The private collection includes a portrait of the late Keith Moon (pictured) who died from a drug overdose at the age of 32          The collection includes a copy of debut album My Generation, signed by the four original band members. Pictured: John at his home in October 1966          Famous friends: This photograph shows Roger Daltrey again in Charing Cross in May 1966           Swinging Sixties: Here John Entwistle chats to friends in Charing Cross in 1966           Empty streets: Road manager Neville sports a pair of now-fashionable tight trousers and a sweatshirt in Charing Cross as the band travelled the city in 1966           Roadies: The Who's road managers Gordon and Neville at Regent's Park in May 1966           Iconic: Among the rare collection is a signed copy of the My Generation album cover           Arrivals: Roger Daltrey pictured with three friends after arriving back at London's Heathrow following his American tour in June 1966 A Royal thank you! The Queen hails the 'tenacity, skill and...Grab a slice of 'Britain's St Tropez': Stunning seaside home...Share this article    Having fun: Bandmates John Entwistle and Keith Moon with a friend at Charing Cross in May 1966  Pictured: Pete Townsend – lead guitar, backing and lead vocals from 1964 to present - photographed at Heathrow in October 1967           Back in London! Peter Townsend dressed smartly for his arrival back in the UK following his second tour of the USA in October 1967           Collection: The items belonged to Gaby McGee, a fan turned friend of Roger Daltrey, and were inherited by her nephew           Off-duty: Here John relaxed at home with his partner in October 1966, after a whirlwind two years of touring with his bandmates           Fooling around: Gaby followed The Who around the country, greeting the band at Heathrow Airport when they returned from their early tours of the USAFrontman Daltrey was supporting The Beatles in 1964 with his former band The High Numbers when he spotted Gaby waiting for an autograph beside the stage doors.Gaby followed The Who around the country, greeting the band at Heathrow Airport when they returned from their early tours of the USA.She even photographed visits to John Entwistle's house and Daltrey's flat in London.Gaby's nephew, Kristian Horne, had the collection valued at Wessex Auction Rooms in Wiltshire.Auctioneer Martin Hughes believes the photos and vinyls will fetch between £1000-£2000 when they go under the hammer on July 13.          Following fan: Gaby even photographed visits to John Entwistle's house in October 1966           Nice ride! Gaby's interest in the band saw her travel the country with them - taking a photograph here of Roger Daltrey's beloved Volvo, parked at Regent's Park in May 1966          Flying high: Gaby greeted the band at Heathrow after their personalised plane (centre) arrived back from tour in April 1967          Gaby's nephew, Kristian Horne, had the collection valued at Wessex Auction Rooms in WiltshireHe said: 'I sat down with the collection to begin cataloging them for our specialist vinyl and music auction.'After I had finished I looked into the bottom of the vintage record case and found a small envelope and when I looked inside I couldn't believe what I found.'There were 21 candid photos of the band taken by the seller's Auntie in various locations in 1966 and 1967 - many of which had been signed by the members of the band.'There is one particular photograph that is just Keith with his signature very clearly written to the front. It's my favourite picture from the collection and he looks so iconic.'To me it's priceless to have such a candid shot signed by the legend himself.'The band's drummer Keith Moon died in 1978 and his autograph is considered a rarity by collectors - as is a collection of all four signatures together.Bids from around the world are expected when they auctioned at Wessex.An ultra rare vinyl demo of The Beatles first single, Love Me Do, will also be available - and is expected to sell for up to £7000.           The items belonged to Gaby McGee, a fan turned friend of Roger Daltrey, and were inherited by her nephew          The band's drummer Keith Moon died in 1978 and his autograph is considered a rarity by collectors - as is a collection of all four signatures together           Frontman Daltrey was supporting The Beatles in 1964 with his former band The High Numbers when he spotted Gaby waiting for an autograph beside the stage doors

story: Prince Charles proudly displayed his military medals and breast stars at the Westminster Abbey service today. Meghan and Kate compete in the style...Share this articleOrder of Merit            Awarded to those who provided outstanding service in the armed forces, or science, art, literature. There can only be a total of 24 members of the OMAwarded to those who provided outstanding service in the armed forces, or science, art, literature. There can only be a total of 24 members of the OM.As with the Royal Victorian Order, the Order of Merit is in the sole gift of the Sovereign but carries no rank apart from the initials OM after the name. The Prince of Wales was awarded the Order of Merit on June 26, 2002. Aircrew badge           The aircrew badge, commonly referred to as 'wings', is the badge worn on the left breast, above any medal ribbons, by qualified aircrewThe aircrew badge, commonly referred to as 'wings', is the badge worn on the left breast, above any medal ribbons, by qualified aircrew. Prince Charles trained as a jet pilot at RAF Cranwell in 1971. He completed his helicopter training three years later.Queen's Service Order          The Order was instituted by the Queen in 1975 on the advice of her New Zealand ministers, and The Prince was installed in 1983The Order was instituted by the Queen in 1975 on the advice of her New Zealand ministers and the Prince was installed in 1983. Coronation Medal           The Queen Elizabeth II Coronation Medal was awarded to the Prince to mark the Queen's coronation in 1953Awarded to the Prince to mark the Queen's coronation in 1953. Silver Jubilee Medal           Awarded to Prince Charles in 1977 to mark his mother's 25-year reign as QueenAwarded to Prince Charles in 1977 to mark his mother's 25-year reign as Queen. Golden Jubilee Medal 2002          Given to the Prince of Wales in 2002 for the Queen's Golden JubileeGiven to the Prince of Wales in 2002 for the Queen's Golden Jubilee.  Diamond Jubilee Medal 2012          To mark 60 the Queen's 60 years on the throne, Prince Charles was given the Diamond Jubilee MedalTo mark the Queen's 60 years on the throne, Prince Charles was given the Diamond Jubilee Medal.Long Service Good Conduct Medal          Awarded to the Prince last year. The medals, which recognise the good conduct of armed forces personnel over a 15-year period, have now been extended to include military officersAwarded to the Prince last year. The medals, which recognise the good conduct of armed forces personnel over a 15-year period, have now been extended to include military officers.They are believed to be the oldest medal still being awarded and can be traced back to 1830.Canadian Forces Decoration           Prince Charles was awarded a second clasp to his Canadian Forces Decoration medal in recognition of his 32 years of honorary service as Colonel In Chief of the Royal Canadian RegimentPrince Charles was awarded a second clasp to his Canadian Forces Decoration medal in recognition of his 32 years of honorary service as Colonel In Chief of the Royal Canadian Regiment.He was first given the medal in 1991. The New Zealand Commemorative Medal           These medals were only awarded in 1990 and marks the Prince's special relationship with New ZealandThese medals were only awarded in 1990 and marks the Prince's special relationship with New Zealand.New Zealand Armed Forces          The New Zealand Armed Forces Award is a circular silver medal. It was given to Prince Charles in 2012The New Zealand Armed Forces Award is a circular silver medal. The obverse bears the crowned effigy of Her Majesty The Queen surrounded by the inscription ELIZABETH II DEI GRATIA REGINA FID. DEF.Prince Charles was given the award in 2012. The Most Notable Order of the Garter (Knight)          The Order of the Garter - formally the Most Noble Order of the Garter - is an order of chivalry founded by Edward III in 1348 and regarded as the most prestigious British order of chivalryThe Order of the Garter - formally the Most Noble Order of the Garter - is an order of chivalry founded by Edward III in 1348 and regarded as the most prestigious British order of chivalry. Appointments are made at the Sovereign's sole discretion. Membership of the Order is limited to the Sovereign, the Prince of Wales, and no more than 24 living members, or Companions. Prince Charles was inducted into the order in 1968.The Most Ancient and the Most Noble Order of the Thistle (Knight)The Most Ancient and Most Noble Order of the Thistle was was founded in 1687 by King James VII of Scotland.The Order consists of the Sovereign and sixteen Knights and Ladies, as well as certain 'extra' knights (members of the British Royal Family and foreign monarchs). The Sovereign alone grants membership of the Order.  Prince Charles was made a member of the Order in 1977.PRINCE WILLIAM   Prince William also had his military medals on display as he stepped out for the service  William wore his RAF 'Wings' above his Jubilee service medals and Order of the Garter star Aircrew badge The aircrew badge, commonly referred to as 'wings', is the badge worn on the left breast, above any medal ribbons, by qualified aircrew. Prince William received his Wings from Prince Charles at the RAF Cranwell air base in Lincolnshire after successfully completing an intensive flying course in title: Largest family 87 year old 346 living descendants including 203 great grandchildren
story: Everybody squeeze in! The Semenyuk family in Ukraine consists of 346 living relatives, with the oldest member 87-year-old Pavel (sat front, holding certificate) and youngest a two-week-old newborn baby          Pavel Semenyuk (centre) is awarded by Ukraine's National Register of Records for having the largest family in the countryThe Semenyuk family lives in the village of Dobroslav in southern Ukrainian Odessa Oblast region.Pavel might have considered himself fortunate to have 13 kids, but now with a total of 127 grandchildren, 203 great-grandchildren and even three great-great-grandchildren, he is being recognised for something truly out of the ordinary.It's all one big happy family, the retired construction worker said, mentioning the only difficulty is remembering all the names of his descendants. More than 2,500 women shed their clothes and e into the...Share this article'I know the names of those who are older. But I often cannot remember the names of the young ones,' Pavel said.Each time one of them gets a family, others build a new house in the village for the newly married pair.To do so, there are no shortage of willing hands as most of Pavel's sons, grandsons and great grandson are also in the construction business.          The Semenyuk family started with construction worker Pavel who had 13 children, before ending up with 127 grandchildren,  203 great-grandchildren and three great-great-grandchildren          Each family occasion is celebrated with an extra-large gathering. The women will cook huge pots of food for birthdays and weddingsReportedly 30 children from the Semenyuk family attend the local school and every birthday and wedding is a big event for the whole family.One of Pavel's daughters Vira Semenyuk, 66, said:'We cook huge pots of food to celebrate our birthdays and weddings. The women always help each other.'          Currently, there are 30 Semenyuk children at the local schoolA few days ago the Semenyuk family were recognised as the largest family in Ukraine. Their names were registered in the local National Register of Records and they are to be submitted to Guinness World Records.The head of the National Register of Records Lana Vetrova said: 'This is a unique family. Until now the world's largest family consisted of 192 members and was registered in India by Guinness World Records.'The Semenyuks have a good chance to break that record.'

title: Astrophysics student took life amid exam stress
story: Student Joel Rees took his own life after suffering from exam stress, an inquest has foundJoel's mother Stephanie Perkin said her son was 'very determined, bright and a determination to succeed'.But he felt pressure over exams a month before he died and walked out of one exam because it was 'too difficult'.She added he had a 'fear of failure' and spent a lot of time working and revising.Joel's father David Rees said his son 'set high standards for himself' but in his first year was 'enjoying life and there were no major issues'.Heartbroken father reveals how his search for his missing...Share this articleHe later got a job in a supermarket deli to support himself and worried he did not have enough time to study.Mr Rees said Joel had emailed lecturers about the 'completely unreasonable' deadlines but was told he could retake exams if needed.He added that his son was 'always independent and would not ask for help', but he would have happily given him money if needed.Fellow student Timothy Pickering told the inquest Joel was depressed and on medication but 'did not want to burden his family'.          Joel's family told a coroner he had walked out of one exam shortly before he was found deadHe said the new drug he was prescribed was 'not really working and made him feel worse'. Devon coroner Philip Spinney heard Joel was found dead, lying clothed on a bed. An autopsy concluded that he died from asphyxiation, suffocation and the inhalation of organic solvents.Mr Spinney recorded a verdict of suicide, adding: 'I am satisfied that Joel took his own life and intended to do so.'It is plain from the evidence that Joel struggled with his mental health over a number of years.'Clearly it is an issue that just does not affect here but across the country there is an increase in mental health issues affecting students in universities and I hope from a tragic event like this that lessons can be learned.'A University of Exeter spokesman said: 'We remain deeply saddened by this tragic case, and our thoughts and sympathies continue to be with Joel's family and friends at this incredibly sad and difficult time.'We encourage all students who are experiencing mental health difficulties of any kind to seek the appropriate support and help, and have robust arrangements in place with local health trusts and services to share information and refer students for the appropriate treatment if it is believed they are at risk.'These arrangements are reviewed regularly to ensure they offer the best possible care and support. The University's Wellbeing Services also offers a broad range of services of students who need support, while we also work to ensure academic tutors are trained to understand the difficulties faced by students experiencing mental health difficulties.' For confidential support call the Samaritans in the UK on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

title: Storm Chris bring end Heatwave Britain
story: Sisters Catherine Lingard, eight (left) and Lottie Lingard, two (right) enjoyed an ice cream in the sun as they celebrated Catherine's birthday at Bournemouth beachThis graphic shows the temperature across the country as well as the wind speed, precipitation and air pressure while Storm Chris develops on the other side of the Atlantic. It also shows how the UK compares to other countries on the continent.           Football fan Amy Wray got out and enjoyed the sun and warm weather in Newquay, Cornwall today Met Office spokeswoman Nicola Maxey said while storm Chris will affect the UK, 'we cannot tell what that influence will be at the moment because it is still developing'.There is still 'uncertainty' about the possible track it will take and it would be an ex-hurricane by the weekend when it may hit the UK.Much-needed rain is on the way but it is still too early to write off the summer as warm weather is still expected over the coming week.Apartment which serves up smashing views of Wimbledon's...The tragedy behind the man who wants to break England¿s...Poundworld will close 25 stores causing the loss of 242 jobs...Share this articleAverage summer temperatures are 19C (66F) but across the UK we have seen 10C above that, according to Ms Maxey.She said a 'blip' in the current hot weather, which is not down to Chris, is seeing temperatures in the south east drop to around 23-25C (73-77F) and further north to 21-22C (69-71F) in Birmingham or 17-18C (62-64F) in Newcastle but temperatures 'will increase a few degrees to the weekend'.      Meteorologist Aidan McGivern, speaking in a Met Office Facebook post, said: 'Developments on the other side of the pond could very well disrupt weather patterns in the vicinity of the UK.'Tropical storm Chris is predicted to become a hurricane and move north over the next few days.'(By the weekend) Chris is likely to join the jet stream and its remnants are likely to be carried towards the UK. Now, those uncertainties mean there are big differences in the forecast for the start of next week.'One projection showing low pressure just to the west of the UK is bringing wind and rain, but on another Chris is barely there.'One common theme emerging from the start of next week is that low pressure will be a little closer and the weather will turn more changeable than we have seen recently.' Ms Maxey said: 'Certainly next week after ex-hurricane Chris has passed through we are looking at weather that is more mobile or normal (for this time of year) but that is not to say that we will not have another hot spell of weather.'She said that ex-hurricanes like Chris happen regularly. This interactive module, which is continuously updated, represents the picture across the UK. It shows high pressure sweeping across the country creating the warm and pleasant conditions seen over the weekend and into this week. Generated by a super computer and updated every three hours by the National Weather Service, the graph shows winds sweeping across the Atlantic and the Channel.           Sun worshippers enjoyed the heatwave at the beach in Bournemouth, Dorset, making the most of the warm weather as an approaching cold front is forecast to break the sizzling temperatures

title: RAF Centenary Flypast Watch highlights 100 aircraft took skies London
story: Chinooks from RAF Odiham flew in the lead formation, along with Pumas from RAF Benson, for the RAF100 flypast          The RAF's iconic Red Arrows fill the London sky with red, white and blue to bring today's historic fly-past to a close todayThe formation then continued over the M25, Stapleford Abbotts, Hainault Forest and on to central London – passing the Olympic Park, Hackney, Bethnal Green and Shoreditch before getting to The Mall at around 1pm.It was on April 1, 1918 that the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service merged to create the RAF - the world's first independent air service.          Red Arrows fly past the Winston Churchill statue in Parliament Square, trailing red white and blue smoke, to conclude the RAF100 fly-past today          One of the Red Arrows unleashes its red mist as it passes over the River Thames and the London Eye, as the formation prepares to pass over The Mall
