title: sun says theresa may brexit marxism
story: The Chequers compromise is bad enough — though we understand the necessity of this minority Government buying off the Remainers who dominate Parliament and who would kill Brexit entirely given the chance.But many Tory MPs and Leave voters already consider it a complete betrayal. The Sun sees no further red lines she can cross without self-destruction.So EU negotiator Michel Barnier and his puppet-masters Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron need to be very careful how far they push back.Impossible demands will destabilise and bring down the Government.Let’s be blunt. This fudge is the result of the PM’s dithering and failure to plan for “no deal” — that essential weapon of any negotiator’s armoury.Had she won the 100-plus majority predicted before last year’s election things would be different. But her disastrous campaign put paid to that.Michael Gove claims her Chequers offer would secure Brexit and free us to move further away in time. We are highly doubtful but we hope he’s right.To us, a proper Brexit, which would have made us a freer, richer country and was backed by a 17.4 million majority, has been given up without a fight.Remainer Tories MUST study the polls showing their party could now face an election wipeout as their core voters desert them. title: parasitic worm schistosomiasis lays eggs human organs europe
story: And schistosomiasis - also known as snail fever - could be set to invade Europes shores.Around 25-30% of humans are currently infected with at least one parasitic worm species, writes Karl Hoffmann, Professor of Parasitology at Aberystwyth University, for The Conversation.The diseases they cause can be devastating.Worm infections can lead to diverse and chronic conditions such as scarring of the eyes and blindness, swelling of extremities and immobility, blockage of digestion and malnutrition, anaemia and tiredness.They can also increase an individual’s risk of developing cancer and AIDS.Schistosomiasis currently affects hundreds of millions of people each year, causing thousands of deaths.Caused by schistosome flatworms, the infection occurs when people come into contact with a type of freshwater snail that produces the worms.These worms then penetrate the skin and live in the blood vessels surrounding the intestines or bladder of the individual.When the eggs of these flatworms become trapped in human organs, they can cause inflammation, blindness, scarring, anaemia and ultimately, death.Any eggs that make it into the digestive system will be released when the carrier defecates or urinates. If these then reach fresh water, they can hatch and the cycle begins again.While Schistosomiasis was previously linked to impoverished parts of South America, sub-Saharan Africa where water hygiene is limited, recent outbreaks were reported on the Mediterranean.In 2014,  six people were infected after swimming in the Cavu river, in Corsica.And, according to Professor Hoffmann, global travel and climate change could mean we see parasitic worms continuing to move into parts of Europe and North America.The long-term consequences of increased parasitic worm distributions are difficult to predict, but the harm that infection causes highlights the need for developing control strategies that can mitigate this 21st-century threat to global health.Hoffman and his team are looking into ways to treat and prevent the spread of  parasitic diseases.We’re not at the stage of drug development, but we hope that learning more about the disruption of these proteins could ultimately save lives across the world, he wrote.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: incredible pictures reveal lost tribe isolated for 55000 years on tiny indian ocean islands
story: Only 400 members of the Jarawa tribe remain on the Andaman Islands, in the Indian Ocean, and its feared they could be wiped out in the next ten years.The greatest threat to their existence is a highway which cuts straight through their ancestral home, according to charity Survival International.The road brings tourists to the territory who are accused of treating the Jarawa like animals in a safari park.Meanwhile poachers are believed to enter the rich forests of the reclusive islands and hunt the game the tribe needs to survive.This is one of the many reasons the Jarawa are hostile towards outsiders, having lived in harmony with the land for so many generations.The nomadic tribespeople are master hunters who trap pigs, lizards and turtles with a specially made Jarawa bow.Being an island-dwelling tribe, food sources in the ocean are vital to their survival and men often catch fish in the shallows.They are also understood to love fruit and honey, extracting it from hives by using special plant extracts to calm the bees.They are said to have detailed knowledge of more than 150 plant and 350 animal species on the island.The Jarawa also have reputations as as warriors and uncompromising defenders of their territory.They lived through both British colonisation in the 19th century and then Japanese occupation later on.In 1998, a few Jarawa started to emerge from their forest for the first time without their bows and arrows to visit other settlements.But in 1990 local authorities revealed a long-term master plan to settle them in two villages with an economy based on fishery.The plan went as far as to suggest what style of clothes the Jarawa should now wear.Forced settlement had been fatal for other tribes in the Andaman Islands, according to Survival International.Following a passionate campaign by Survival and other Indian organisations, the resettlement plan was abandoned in the early 2000s.

title: meghan markle price harry ireland visit dublin green givenchy dress
story: The newlyweds touched down in Dublin today for the start of their first overseas official trip since they said I do in May.Earlier in the day, the Duchess chose a stunning emerald green Givenchy dress in a nod to her Irish hosts as she joined her husband Prince Harry for the start of a historic two-day visit to Ireland.The choice of colour was also seen as a tribute to her grandmother-in-law who wore green on her first trip to Ireland too.For the evening, Meghan chose a simple sleeveless black belted dress by Emilia Wickstead that showed off her enviably slim figure, finished off with a pair of plain black heels and a simple clutch bag.The Duchess also chose to leave her hair loose, marking a significant change to her usual tied style since her wedding in May.It appeared that Meghan was channelling her inner Audrey Hepburn for the second time in a day by choosing a black dress to step out in.This morning, the newest Royal was seen in a black ensemble by Givenchy as she stood alongside the Queen for the RAF centenary celebrations at Buckingham Palace.Harry and Meghan touched down in a private chartered jet at Dublin Airport this afternoon for their first official overseas tour as a married couple.The trip is the latest in a series of foreign royal visits to EU member states in the wake of Brexit, with the soft diplomacy jaunt expected to strengthen relationships with countries as Britain breaks away from the EU.The two-day trip will include a look at a Gaelic sports festival and an exhibit about the Irish famine, and will allow the couple to celebrate Ireland, its culture and its people.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were warmly welcomed by the Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar as they arrived at Dublins Government Buildings - the Irish equivalent of 10 Downing Street.On arrival, the happy couple were shown a plaque laid by Harrys great, great, great grandfather King Edward VII in 1904.The pair were shown a inside where they viewed a stained glassed window representing the four provinces of Ireland - Leinster, Munster, Connaught and Ulster- which prompted a quick chat about the rugby.Former sports minister Mr Varadkar asked rugby fan Harry if he had watched the England versus Ireland game to which he replied: Which one?”The couple turned to wave at large crowds who had gathered behind a rope in a sealed off corridor to catch a coveted glimpse.They were then taken to Mr Varadkars private offices where they were introduced to a number of employees including 18-year-old intern Tabitha Owen, from London, who is on a short summer secondment before starting a PPE degree at Oxford in September.Despite being the newest member of the Royal household, Meghan seemed at ease with the agenda and remained her husband, it was: Time to sign the visitors book.After briefly discussing who should sign first Harry picked up the fountain pen.Signing simply Harry, the Duke joked: I never sign big enough. Then when Meghan - a former calligrapher - signed her name with a flourish, he added: Yours is much nicer than mine.The trip to Dublin is not the first time the Duke and Duchess have been away since their May 19 wedding, which fused tradition with modernity and diversity.The couple managed to slip away unnoticed for their honeymoon, of which the destination continues to remain a mystery.Just hours before setting off for Ireland, the couple stood on the Buckingham Palace balcony alongside the Monarch and other members of the Royal household for the RAF centenary celebrations.Meghan stood regally next to the 92-year-old Queen, as the newest Royal witnessed the biggest flypast in recent memory.The Royal Family this afternoon gathered on the famous balcony to watch as 100 aircraft took to the skies for the celebrations.The Queen particularly seemed delighted with the air show, smiling and clapping as the array of aircrafts, including Red Arrows and Hercules, flew over the palace.

title: mcdonalds burger fries ebay price bidders

title: giant crocodile caught australia eight year hunt
story: Rangers in the Northern Territories (NT) finally captured Katherine River’s biggest croc — weighing in at a whopping 1323 lbs.The hunt began after rumours of a “large dark tail” spotted near a local boat ramp, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.NT Parks and Wildlife rangers Chris Heydon and John Burke said it was very unusual to capture a croc this big in the Katherine River system.“We average a 4.2 metre (13.7ft) croc most years, but never this big,” Mr Burke said.Despite its colossal weight, rangers said the male reptile, who could possibly be over 60 years old, was not that difficult to trap.Mr Heydon said: “When they are this big we just sedate them, so there is no chance of us getting chomped.”The reptile will be taken to a crocodile farm in the Katherine region, Northern Territories Parks and Wildlife confirmed.In the Northern Territories inland waters, a 15ft saltwater crocodile is considered to be rare.“Although this is the biggest we’ve caught in the Katherine River, there are bigger ones out there that come up from the Daly River,” ranger Burke said.The NT Parks and Wildlife are reminding the community to “be crocwise”.On their website they make it clear that “croc danger is real”.“Do not become complacent or risk your life.”Croc captures are not unusual in the in the region, earlier this year seven crocodiles were pulled from the river, including two large saltwater crocs — 12.8ft and 15ft in length.There was an even a larger find in Darwin, when rangers were called to capture a 4.7m croc from the city’s harbour.Across the region, there have been 188 saltwater crocodiles captured so far this year while 370 were captured in 2017.Hope Inlet, located in the Northern Territory’s northwest, has had the most croc captures this year at 42.In 1974 a 21ft saltwater croc was caught on the Mary River in a net.A version of this story first appeared on news.au

story: Theresa May has ordered “no deal” planning “to step up” — with the government poised to start unveiling some of the 300 contingency measures in the coming weeks.At last week’s Chequers summit, Brexiteer ministers demanded more be done to prepare for Britain leaving the EU out without a new arrangement in place.The Sun can reveal that includes emergency measures to keep Britain’s massive food and drinks industry afloat - story: But Schools Minister Nick Gibb said two thirds were now meeting the more rigorous SATs requirements - up from just over a half two years ago.Newly released statistics from the Department for Education showed 64 per cent of year six pupils reached expected standards in literacy and numeracy in 2018, up from 61 per cent last year.Back in 2016 just 53 per cent of pupils made the grade when tougher assessments for key stage two SATs were introduced.To meet the required standard across all subjects, pupils must achieve a scaled score - a score adjusted to allow for accurate comparisons over time - of 100 or more in reading and maths tests.Pupils must also be deemed to be “working to the expected standard” or “working at greater depth” in writing assessments conducted by teachers.Some teachers believe the key stage two tests put excessive pressure on young children and don’t accurately represent a school’s performance.But School standards minister Nick Gibb said: “A good primary education lays the foundations for success at secondary school and beyond.“These results and the rising standards we are seeing in our primary schools are the fruit of our reforms and a tribute to the hard work and dedication of teachers across the country.“These reforms promise even more success in the years to come and will help to improve education for every child, no matter their background.”Julie McCulloch, director of policy at the Association of School and College Leaders, said teachers reported children crying and having nightmares about the assessments.She added: “The problem is not the tests themselves but the fact that they are used as the main way of judging primary schools and the stakes are extremely high.“In reality, four days of tests out of seven years of schooling can never provide anything more than a snapshot.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: its time the middle class start to consider kids who deliver their dinner party coke
story: Then later, oh the irony, they’ll be back online to order “special topping” from a local cocaine dealer who, according to the Global Drug Survey, can now deliver it faster than a pizza.A few weeks ago Simon Kempton, of the Police Federation, stated that it is “white middle class people” driving the epidemic that’s making the UK one of the biggest consumers of cocaine in Europe.And this slang for flogging coke etc in the counties where, consequently, violent crime is now rocketing.Based in London, he ran a gang of country-wide dealers via a mobile he also used to contact eager escaping detection by taking the drugs behind closed doors.So the next time a middle class drug user is about to call their dealer, perhaps they could pause for a moment to consider that while the story: It set a world record for any book illustration sold at auction.It was originally expected to sell for £150,000 when it was first put up for auction.Sotheby’s described the 1926 sketch by E.H. Shepard, none of which had been seen for almost 50 years.In total, the map and other illustrations sold for a combined £917,500 - three times the lower estimate.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: george clooney italy motorbike cctv
story: The Hollywood stars helmet is reported to have shattered when he smashed against the cars windshield at around 60mph.The heart-stopping moment was caught on CCTV, released and obtained by Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera.It shows the Batman and Robin star slam into on-coming traffic before flipping over the handlebars and slamming into the ground.He was found lying in the road with injuries to his pelvis and bruising to his knee and arm following the early morning crash.The actor was driving from his home in Puntaldia to a film set in Olbia when a car, apparently driven by a man in his 60s, suddenly turned into his bike at around 7am.It is believed the man was trying to make a left turning to go to the beach.The double Oscar winner - who is on the island to direct, produce and star in TV series Catch 22 - was thrown from his bike on the road near Costa Corallina, TMZ reported.Images from State Road 125 showed slight damage to his bike while the left side of the car windscreen was badly smashed.The driver called an ambulance and waited with father-of-two Clooney until medics arrived to take him to John Paul II Hospital.A police spokesman said:We were called by a motorist to say they had been in an accident and when we arrived a man was found on the ground.Paramedics were called and he was taken to hospital for treatment. The driver of the car was a local man in his 60s and we are speaking to him about what happened.It was fortunate the man on the motorbike was wearing a helmet as his head hit the windscreen which smashed.His wife Amal, 40, rushed to hospital to be at his side and he was discharged just two hours later.Firefighters were dispatched to the scene of the accident as a safety precaution.Clooney was pictured stepping off a private jet with wife Amal and twins, Alexander and Ella, in Sardinia at the end of last month.Even earlier in June, Clooney was seen zipping around the island on a scooter with Amal, 40, hugging him tightly.The A-list couple are believed to have brought their parents to the island to help care for the children while George works.Clooney has been working hard on Catch 22, a six-episode mini-series based on the novel by Joseph Heller.In April, the legendary thespian announced he was cutting down his acting role in the Hulu production so he could focus on directing.George and Amal met back in 2013 when Amal attended a party at the Oceans Eleven stars house in Lake Como, Italy.It was from that moment George made it his mission to land Amal, later taking her on their first date at a plush London restaurant.She explained in an interview with Vogue: I was 35 when I met him. title: the big singalong flop
story: Instead, it’s left to the commercial broadcaster and poor old Tony Hadley, reaching something close to climax, to sing a hymn of praise to this much-neglected national treasure.At which point, I think it’s probably time to drop the laboured sarcasm, because this next event may have been the point the cult of the NHS met its Waterloo.The Big Singalong Live, from Abbey Road Studios, where the disclaimers were heavier than Wednesday night’s rain as host Sara Cox quickly established: “This was not our idea, was it, Ashley (Banjo)?”“No, no it wasn’t.”The buck was being passed very much in the direction of the Lewisham and Greenwich NHS choir, who had come up with the perfectly ­reasonable idea of breaking television’s singalong record of 6,904 people, with a live version of The Beatles’ song With A Little Help From My Friends.Tireless and talented NHS heroes they may be, but for this thing to fly someone also clearly felt the process required some famous names to get on board.Normally, of course, this is the point when the public realises, “Ah, so it isn’t about us or the NHS at all. It’s about celebrities improving their image.”Oh, but what record-breaking names they’d assembled.Robbie, Adele, Elton, Ed Sheeran, Coldplay and Stormzy, were just a few of those who didn’t attend.Blue, Coleen Nolan, Amber Davies, from last year’s Love Island, UB40, Kimberley Walsh and Tony Hadley, on the other hand, were all involved, as was JLS’s Aston Merrygold, right, who said, on behalf of the NHS, he was: “Happy to clear my diary.”So we thank him and whoever covered the shift at Domino’s.Job demarcation, though, among the celebs, was a bit vague. A few just seemed to have backing track duties, like Kimberley Walsh who was given the line “What would you do if I sang out of tune?” (IF?)Some were enrolled for the full, record-breaking, Abbey Road finale, while others went on recruitment drives at UK hospitals, where Tony unearthed “the singing ambulanceman”, and Sara set her sights on Debbie “who’s pouring custard on a spotted Dick” — in the staff canteen, rather than the Infectious Diseases Unit.Eulogies to the great NHS god, though, were compulsory and delivered with a glassy-eyed, lip-quivering intensity that has become a very familiar sight these past few months.Good intentions, as we know, though, pave the road to hell. And so it proved with Wednesday’s Big Singalong Live, which kicked off with a parp of a klaxon, from Ashley, and Sara screaming: “Can we now please break that record.”Perhaps we can put what followed down to the swirling p***storm, in North London, or the lack of practice time — they only had six weeks — but, dear Lord in heaven — Russell Crowe didn’t unleash this much hell in Gladiator.Missed cues, frozen screens, flat voices, Tony Hadley giving it the big ’un, on the Abbey Road zebra crossing, with his “woh-oh ohhhs”.Seven thousand drunk Millwall fans chanting: “You’re going home in a London ambulance” could not have been much less unco-ordinated, but would undoubtedly have delivered an equally powerful message about the NHS.Salvation, though, was on hand in the form of Sara Cox.“The results are in and . . . (drum roll).“We almost made it, but it looks like the weather may have rained on our parade. We didn’t break the record.” A MASTERCLASS in scheduling, editing and continuity, from Channel 5, on Thursday night, that began with the very chirpy announcement: “We’ll find out What Happened to Josef Fritzl after brand new Nando’s, A PERi PERi Big Success . . . ”Which isn’t the first thing I associate Josef with, to be perfectly honest with you. Though, who knows.The old sod may have loved their Spicy Mixed Olives with a Wing Roulette.Unappetising start or not, I wasn’t going to switch off A PERi PERi Big Success until it had truly unlocked the secret of this much-loved high street dining phenom- enon.Two minutes and 30 seconds into the documentary, bingo. Without the narrator even missing a heartbeat, up popped Vanessa Feltz: “I’d never been in Nando’s until I was doing Strictly with James Jordan. He’d go every single day and I’d trot in straight after him.”“Nando’s empire now stretches from Inverness to Plymouth.” All those clueless ITV presenters desperately trying to clamber aboard the football bandwagon, like Amanda Holden, who kicked off last Friday’s This Morning announcing: “We’re all excited about tomorrow’s World Cup final between England and Sweden.”On the strength of which, I’ve booked a once-in-a-lifetime, cheap-as-you-like caving holiday in Thailand.Column returns some time before Qatar 2022FINALLY, some awards for those fine men and women who really have gone above and beyond the call of pundit and commentating duty during this unforgettable World Cup.STICKING HIS NECK OUT AWARD – Lee Dixon: “France are always French.”HISTORIAN OF THE TOURNAMENT – Ally McCoist: “And of course, the October revolution in Russia took place here in 1977.”KING OF LOGIC – Gary Neville: “By avoiding bigger teams, you avoid them.”GLASS HALF EMPTY TROPHY – Sam Matter- face: “Didier Deschamps has lost this game even though he’s won it.”MATHEMATICIAN OF THE TOURNAMENT – Jurgen Klinsmann: “If nine out of ten are called correct, you won’t worry about the other one or two.”RUNNER-UP – Fabian Delph: “A birth only happens once in a lifetime. This is our third.”BEST USE OF TENSES – Martin Keown: “Both wingbacks will know they are in a game after this has finished.”And THE GRACE UNDER FIRE AWARD – Rebekah Vardy: “The person insulting us is probably a massive fat Russian who doesn’t have any mirrors in the house. They do it to get a reaction. Well, they won’t get one from me.”Attagirl, Becky. You rise above it. (Compiled by Graham Wray).The Chase Australia, Andrew O’Keefe: “What is the capital city of Australia?”Kathleen: “Sydney.”The Chase USA, Brooke Burns: “What’s the two-word motto for both the boy scouts and girl scouts?”Andrew O’Keefe: “Which fashion designer and Dame was the partner of punk icon Malcolm McLaren?”Reh: “Steve McQueen.”Hairdresser Grace desperately searching for common Love Island ground with dreary Doctor Alex: “You save lives and I change lives.”The heartening discovery The Chase’s Bradley Walsh is an infinitely better presenter than Brooke Burns and Andrew O’Keefe, on the US and Australian versions.And BBC1’s The Man, The Voice paying deserved tribute to the soon-to-retire Barry Davies, who as well as being one of Auntie’s most versatile performers was, for many years, by far its most articulate and best football commentator.What a pity the BBC didn’t realise it at the time. “Sorry mate, I didn’t blow you off, were you lurking in the begonias?”“No, just right in front of you.” “Well next time I’ll come and man up and . . . ”Oh get a potting shed, you two.  The Culture Show, Sue Perkins: “It’s 11am and I’m off to watch the fabulous Bridget Christie be funny about feminism.” (See you at 11.05am then).And This Morning, Sam Rubin: “Eamonn, Ruth. This happens all the time with famous people. Tinier than you might think.”Well, Ruth maybe. Not Eamonn.THIS week’s winner is David Tennant and Abu the monkey, from Aladdin. Sent in by Richie James.Picture research, Alfie Snelling.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tech exposes drivers using mobiles
story: A scanner senses if a phone is in use in a car — and a symbol of a mobile with a line through it then flashes up on a sign as drivers pass.A trial of the £6,000 equipment started in Norwich yesterday and will move to other Norfolk locations during the next month.It will not record plates or issue fines but data will be shared with police. It is also unable to tell whether a driver or passenger is using a handset.But officials hope the kit will help remind people of the dangers of using phones while driving.Norfolk County Council’s Road Safety team has developed the technology in partnership with vehicle sign technology firm Westcotec.Westcotec’s Chris Spinks said he hoped it could provide police with an idea of where illegal use is most common. He said: “The aim of the technology is to remind drivers of the law and to get off their phones.”Jonathan Chapman, inspector of the Norfolk Roads Policing Unit, added: “We will be using the information to help us target drivers in the future but the message is simple — leave your phone alone whilst you’re behind the wheel.”Margaret Dewsbury, chairman of Norfolk County Council’s communities committee, said: “Using a mobile phone whilst driving is an enormous distraction and apart from being illegal puts the lives of the driver, passengers and pedestrians at risk.”Those caught using mobile phones at the wheel face a £200 fine and six points on their licence following the introduction of tougher laws last year. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new health secretary matt hancock
story: NewsNew Health Secretary Matt Hancock was paid £32,000 by anti-NHS think-tank bossMr Hancock, 39, has accepted nine donations worth from pal Neil Record, chairman of the pro-privatisation Institute of Economic Affairs, according to official records&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor22:58, 10 JUL 2018NewsHealth Secretary Matt Hancock accepted £32,000 over nine payments from an anti-NHS pal (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHealth Secretary Matt Hancock has accepted &pound32,000 from the chairman of a think-tank which wants to scrap the NHS. He also took &pound5,000 from the director of a private nursing firm which supplies agency workers to the health service. The donations will raise questions about the 39-year-old’s commitment to the NHS and could embroil him in a conflict of interest row. Theresa May promoted Mr Hancock from Culture Secretary to Health Secretary on Monday after predecessor Jeremy Hunt replaced Boris Johnson as Foreign Secretary. Shadow Health Minister Justin Madders said: “The NHS is our national treasure so it’s a disgrace that Theresa May has appointed a health secretary with links to organisations that want to break it up and sell it off.” Mr Hancock has accepted nine donations worth &pound32,000 from Neil Record, chairman of the Institute of Economic Affairs, official records show. Mr Record, 65, was appointed chair in 2015 after seven years on its board.  The IEA’s head of health and welfare, Dr Kristian Niemietz, has called for the NHS to be privatised and replaced with a private insurance-based system.  Last week, on the 70th birthday of the NHS, the IEA described the service as an “international laggard”, adding that “it  is time to look to the social health insurance systems in Europe”.  Mr Hancock also accepted &pound5,000 in March 2015 from Gurdev Dadral, the director of private nursing agency Swiis, a Mirror investigation found. Mr Dadral could not be reached for comment. There is no suggestion Mr Hancock has broken any rules. But Mr Madders said: “The new Health Secretary must urgently explain whether he still has links with private healthcare firms. “Our NHS is not for sale.” The Department of Health declined to comment tonight. A Government source did not deny the donations had been made but said any suggestion Mr Hancock was contemplating privatising or abolishing the NHS was “wholly wrong”.

title: england team helped reclaim flag
story: NewsopinionEngland team have helped us reclaim our flag and our pride, says Eva SimpsonWith England just two games away from winning the World Cup, it really feels great to have something that we can all rally around, something that brings the whole country together&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEva Simpson22:57, 10 JUL 2018NewsopinionDele Alli scores the second goal against Sweden in the quarter-final (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLast Saturday at 2.30pm I was in a race against time to get my 12-year-old son and six of his friends back home from his &shybirthday party to see England’s crunch World Cup quarter-final match against Sweden.  We missed Harry Maguire’s opening goal, but we made it back in time to see Dele Alli head us into tomorrow night’s semi-final in Moscow.  The boys were so happy I thought they would burst. They were screaming, jumping on the sofas and hugging each other so much anyone would have thought they were in the winning team. What made the moment so poignant for me was the fact that Joshua’s friends are all from such diverse backgrounds – Ghana, India, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, England –and they were all united behind the national team. I was surprised to get WhatsApp messages from family in America telling me they are backing England all the way. And later that evening driving past an England fan waving a huge St George’s Flag in South London, my aunty insisted on rolling down the car window and shouting, “Come on, England” in her loudest Accra accent and beeping my car horn. “Yeah!” he screamed back.   This talented England team under manager Gareth Southgate have brought the country together in a way I’ve never seen before.  It made me think back to when I was my son’s age. Would I, aged 12, in the late 1980s ever have sat down with my friends to cheer on the England football team? No I wouldn’t.  Growing up in South London, I feared English football fans and the English flag they brandished so menacingly. The St George’s Cross was hijacked by extreme nationalist groups such as the BNP and National Front which used it as their emblem.  For me, my family and friends it signified that, to many people in this country, we weren’t welcome. My memory of English fans then was as drunken, rampaging yobs who felt it was acceptable to hurl vile racist abuse at their own players.  John Barnes has spoken about the abuse he faced on the pitch. The former England player, who had a banana thrown at him during a 1988 FA Cup tie at Everton, said: “Any black player of my generation had it. In 1984 with England in Brazil, I had it with the National Front. There wasn’t a game in the Eighties when you didn’t get racial abuse as a black player.”

title: government issues travel advice holidaymakers
story: NewsGovernment issues travel advice for holidaymakers flying to Spain on their summer breakThe list includes tips to avoid scams and protect yourself from street crime&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKate Mcmullin16:09, 10 JUL 2018Updated00:33, 11 JUL 2018NewsPictured: Spanish police officers in Malaga. The government say some thieves in the country fraudulently pose as officers (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe British government have issued a series of safety tips for holidaymakers heading to Spain on holiday. Spain is widely known to be a safe country to enjoy a summer trip to. But while most visits are problem free, recently there have been a few incidents that could cause tourists to worry. Football fans have committed public order offences during the World Cup and there was a recent shooting in Benidorm, reports the Liverpool Echo . Here is a list of things the Government is warning people to look out for to ensure a safe trip. Street crime Holiday goers should be alert to the existence of street crime, especially thieves using distraction techniques. Thieves often work in teams of two or more people and tend to target money and passports.  Don’t carry all your valuables in one place, and remember to keep a photocopy or scanned copy of your passport somewhere safe. Many people have their passports stolen while passing through airports, either on arrival in or departure from Spain. Take extra care to guard passports, money and personal belongings when collecting or checking in luggage at the airport, and while arranging car hire. There has been an increase in the number of thefts from hire cars. Remove all valuables from the vehicle when you park or store items out of sight. In some city centres and resorts, thieves posing as police officers may approach tourists and ask to see their wallets for identification purposes. If this happens to you, establish that the officers are genuine and if necessary show some other form of ID.  Genuine police officers don’t ask to see wallets or purses. In any emergency, call 112. To report a crime, including stolen property and lost or stolen passports, visit the nearest Policia Nacional, regional police (Ertzaintza in the Basque Country, Mossos d’Esquadra in Catalonia, and Policia Foral in Navarre) or Guardia Civil Station to file a police report (denuncia). While in Spain, you can also call a dedicated English-speaking police line on +34 90 210 2112.  World Cup Following public order incidents after televised England matches in Benidorm, fans watching England's semi final clash with Croatia are being advised to xercise caution around the vicinity of Rinc&oacuten Loix. If you’re in the area, you should follow the instructions and advice of the local authorities strict controls on drinking alcohol in the street are in force and anti-social behaviour may lead to prosecution. Attacks Personal attacks, including sexual assaults, are rare but they do occur, and are often carried out by other British nationals. Be alert to the possibility of ‘date rape’ drugs and other drugs including ‘GHB’ and liquid ecstasy. Buy your own drinks and keep sight of them at all times to make sure they aren’t spiked.  Burglaries There has been an increase in reports of burglaries in areas with holiday accommodation and residential areas in major cities. Make sure your accommodation has adequate security measures in place and lock all doors and windows at night or when you aren’t in.  Driving When driving, be wary of approaches by bogus police officers in plain clothes travelling in unmarked cars. In all traffic-related matters, police officers will be in uniform, and all police officers, including those in plain clothes, carry official ID. Unmarked police vehicles have a flashing electronic sign on the rear window which reads Polic&iacutea (Police) or Guardia Civil (Civil Guard), and normally have blue flashing lights. Genuine police officers will only ask you to show them your documents and will not ask for your bag or wallet/purse. If in any doubt, you should talk through the car window and contact the Civil Guard on 062 or Police on 112 and ask them to confirm that the registration number of the vehicle corresponds to an official police vehicle.  Also be aware of ‘highway pirates’ who target foreign-registered and hire cars, especially those towing caravans. Some will (forcefully) try to make you stop, claiming there is something wrong with your car or that you have damaged theirs. If you decide to stop to check the condition of your/their vehicle, stop in a public area with lights like a service station, and be extremely wary of anyone offering help. Only use officially registered or licensed taxis. Lottery scams There have been reports of lottery scams in Spain. A person receives what appears to be official notification from the Spanish Inland Revenue office (Hacienda) that they’ve won the Spanish lottery and should deposit money in a bank account to receive their winnings. It’s likely to be a scam if you haven’t entered a lottery, you’re asked to pay anything up-front and the contact telephone number is for a mobile phone.  Balcony falls There have been a number of very serious accidents (some fatal) as a result of falls from balconies. Many of these incidents have involved British nationals under the influence of drink or drugs. Your travel insurance may not cover you for incidents that take place while you’re under the influence of drink or drugs. Some local councils will impose fines to those caught behaving irresponsibly on balconies or practising ‘balconing’.  Outdoor activities Take care when swimming in the sea as some beaches, especially around Spanish Islands, may have strong undercurrents. Most of them have a flag system but before swimming, make sure you understand the system and follow any warnings (a red flag means you mustn’t enter the water). You should take extra care if there are no life-guards, flags or signs and follow local advice if jellyfish are present. You should avoid swimming at beaches that are close to rivers and don’t dive into unknown water as hidden rocks or shallow depths can cause serious injury or death. Take care when walking along unmanned beaches close to the water’s edge as some waves can be of an unpredictable size and come in further than expected with strong undertows. Further tips can be found on ABTA’s swim safe pages.  Take extra care when planning a hike or walk to check local weather reports for warnings of extreme heat or cold temperatures. The Catalonia region has started billing negligent climbers, skiers and other adventurers who have to be rescued. Crossing between Spain and Gibraltar Spanish border checks can cause delays when crossing between Spain and Gibraltar. There is no charge to enter or leave Gibraltar. Don’t hand over money if you’re approached by anyone claiming that there is a charge. Road travel Driving rules and customs are different from those in the UK and the accident rate is higher, especially on motorways. You must carry two red warning triangles which should be placed, in the event of an accident or breakdown, in front of and behind the vehicle. You must have a spare wheel and the tools to change it. If at any time you have to leave your vehicle due to an accident or breakdown or while waiting for the arrival of the emergency services, you must wear a reflective vest or you may face a heavy fine.

title: heres how much sleep you
story: NewsHere's how much sleep you have lost since heatwave started and why sleeping with windows open is a BAD ideaMany of us are sleeping alone and many risk home burglary by leaving windows wide open&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills22:57, 10 JUL 2018Updated00:32, 11 JUL 2018NewsThe heatwave is stopping people getting a good night's sleep (Image: Getty Images)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis summer's heatwave has collectively cost Britons more than 471million hours of sleep. And according to a study, 42% of us have also slept with bedroom windows wide open during the last two weeks. The study was carried out by a British mattress brand, in a bid to discover more about the UK’s sleeping habits during this unusual stretch of warm tempreatures. The poll found that most people have switched their duvet for something lighter for a more comfortable night’s rest and one in five have slept apart from their partner at least once to try and stay cool.  www.Ergoflex asked a total of 2,133 about their sleep patterns since the June 25 when the heatwave really began. The overwhelming majority, 88%, of the people taking part in the survey said that they had lost sleep due to the heatwave. And when asked to estimate how much they had lost since the start of June, the average answer was revealed to be 45 minutes per night, per person 10 hours and 30 minutes in total. More than two fifths of the respondents taking part in the poll confessed that they had slept with their bedroom windows wide open for the majority of nights over the past two weeks, posing a risk to home security. story: NewsHouses of horror: Inside some of the grimmest properties council workers and police have faced down the yearsWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES The worst homes in Merseyside with buckets of stale urine, hoarding and filthy homes with people living in squalor&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKate Mcmullin10:00, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese horrific images show some of the worst homes in Merseyside with hoarders keeping rubbish, buckets of stale urine and befouled bed sheets.  The nightmare homes are being featured now after the sordid conditions that Catherine Purcell, 68, was kept in became public for the first time.  Shocking photos showing how Ms Purcell lived were part of a trial against her husband and daughter.  The court heard how Catherine died in a cesspit of her own faeces and bodily fluid which chemically destroyed her mattress and bed base, reports the Liverpool Echo.  Husband John Purcell, 72, and daughter Catherine Purcell junior, 35, were cleared of her manslaughter on July 5, at Liverpool Crown Court.  However they were found guilty of neglecting the disabled great-gran, who died while being eaten alive. A High Court judge handed him 18 months in prison, and Catherine Purcell jnr 12 months in prison, both suspended for two years. Graphic images showed the conditions of her home in the Merseyside town of Kirkby. But the Purcell's rancid property is just one of a number of house of horrors on Merseyside. Here is a look inside six other Merseyside homes and what officials were met with when their doors were opened.  Children forced to live in squalor  These graphic photos reveal a Wirral house of horrors where two children were forced to live in squalor. The alcoholic parents of the children, aged just three and six, were convicted of neglect in 2015 after police uncovered the faeces-littered hovel. The graphic photos reveal soiled linen, pillows and mattresses, dirty dishes piled high in the grubby kitchen and floors covered in rubbish.  Police were appalled after finding a bucket of stale urine in the kitchen, as well as what appeared to be faeces in an upstairs bedroom. Soiled nappies were left lying around the house and stale food had created a haven for germs to breed. The children were taken away from their parents, who cannot be named, after the intervention of social services. Describing the home as filthy and appalling, Judge Dennis Watson, QC, said: This was not something that occurred over night. This was something that developed and became the norm over a period of some months.  Real life Shameless family  This is the home of Ormskirk's real-life Shameless family who used their bath as a toilet. David Fyles was booted out of his council home in Lea Crescent in 2016 after town hall officers uncovered the house of horrors.  A bath was being used as a makeshift lavatory, because the actual toilet was blocked up with rubbish and mouldy food and piles of rubbish were strewn throughout the three-bedroom home. Doors were smashed off their hinges and neighbours reported how foul smells from the property emanated across the town's Scott Estate.  Rotting corpse found upstairs  A rotting corpse was discovered in a squalid Merseyside home from hell by health officers who joked: Have you got a dead body upstairs? Police and council officials were called to the house in Knowsley after locals raised concerns because the windows were covered in dead flies. They entered the rancid home to be confronted by an overbearing stench and saw an upstairs doorway surrounded by thousands of the insects.  The body of a man, the son of the homeowners, was found upstairs. Police arrested his sister and his parents on suspicion of concealing a body but charges were never brought. His sister, a mum-of-two, was later convicted of neglect as her two young children frequently stayed at her parents’ hovel home and were“exposed to risk of illness”. The woman was handed an 18-month community order.  Judge Stephen Everett said the punishment would have been sterner had police delays not impeded the case. He added: We will never know in the days or weeks following your brother’s death why nobody did anything.    Terrified dogs left in 'unbelievable conditions'   Four dogs, one with a broken leg, were found in a sweltering property in Upton. Woody along with his brother, Duncan, and parents, Patch and Lucy, were found in conditions RSCPA inspector Anthony Joynes described as a house of horrors. The dogs were seized by the RSPCA after concerns were raised over their welfare.    The house had oil heaters turned on full blast, had no carpets, holes in the floor and was cluttered with piles of clothing.   Playground for rats and flies  A Toxteth man hoarded so much junk that his house became a playground for rats and flies. Bill Berry, 55, could not move around his house which was filled to the brim with years of takeaway boxes, newspapers and rubbish. He was eventually unable to get upstairs so ended up sleeping on the sofa. Bill told the ECHO about his ordeal after beating his disorder with help from Liverpool Housing Trust (LHT). He told how his hoarding began after he suffered with depression from being bullied and unhappy at work.   Dogs left to die in agony  Owner Andrew Davies failed to tell anyone her ‘Labradoodle’ cross-breeds, named Koda and Hachi, were in her former property, in Walton, after she moved in with her mum and sister. RSPCA Inspector Helen Smith, called to the house by the landlord on August 8, 2016, was confronted by a grim scene. She found the bodies of the dogs, who were brothers, decomposing in the kitchen of the filthy property – next to empty water bowls.

O'Mara, who suffers from cerebral palsy, said he was harassed and hounded by the press and was a mess following the incident. He told ITV Calendar: I'll not mince my words. story: NewsLBC caller says England should lose World Cup because of multiracial team - and Mirror man shuts him downThe man named Ian was ranting on about Britain's multiracial society before stating that the England football team 'doesn't represent him'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills21:33, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who called a radio station to say England's World Cup team should lose because of its multiracial team was shut down by Mirror man Kevin Maguire. 'Ian' called into LBC on Saturday, ahead of England's crunch quarter-final match against Sweden and was soon branded a racist by listeners. He was moaning about Britain's racially diverse society before stating the England football team 'doesn't represent him'. He told the Daily Mirror's Associate Editor Kevin Maguire, who was hosting the talk show, In fact, it represents everything I'm against.  Shockingly the man said: When you are talking about the subject of race, it goes a lot deeper than skin colour. If you turn the average black man instantly white, you'd still be able to recognise him as a black man. That's about race, not colour. But Kevin was not standing for the man's rant.  What's wrong with you? he asked. So do you want England to lose today? And after Ian replied yes, Kevin added: What, because you're so obsessed by race and your bigotry, and your prejudice is so poisonous you want England to lose? I just hate seeing my country destroyed by multiracialism and anything that represents multiracialism, Ian replied.  Kevin gave Ian some advice before ending the conversation. I'd just go and make yourself a nice cup of tea, take it into a darkened room, get a bag of frozen peas from the freezer and put them on your head, and just reflect on what you're saying. The England team, who play in the World Cup semi-final tomorrow night against Croatia, have been widely praised.

title: meghan markles visit dublin five
story: NewsMeghan Markle's visit to Dublin five years ago was for a very different reason - and involved €2 drinksWill Meghan take Harry back to Dicey's Garden where she promoted €2 drink in 2013? Probably not if their packed agenda is anything to go by&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks18:38, 10 JUL 2018Updated18:47, 10 JUL 2018NewsToday's trip to Dublin is very different to the last (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and new husband Prince Harry have touched down in Dublin as they embark on a two-day trip around the Irish capital. But it's not the first time the former actress has visited the area - and in 2013 she appeared to enjoy quite the trip to promote &pound1.77 drinks. Five years ago, when Meghan and Harry were not even aware of each other's existence, she was starring in the American drama series, Suits, as character Rachel Zane. And along with pals she visited Dublin's Dicey's Garden, which describes itself as the most popular venue this side of town, and boasts drinks for just €2 (&pound1.77). She posted to her fans: Dublin, you are beyond lovely. Having the best day and excited for a night @diceysgarden and @krystlenightclub xoxo.  The now Duchess of Sussex then continued the evening at Krystle nightclub, overlooking Dicey's Garden. But it's probably very different to where Meghan will be visiting during this week's trip. Dicey's Garden has mixed reviews, as well as a 3.5 rating on Trip Advisor, with 35 per cent rating it 'excellent', while 23 per cent branding it 'terrible.' I would recommend to wear shoes you don’t mind getting ruined as you stick to the floor, one reviewer wrote last month. Another added two weeks ago: The state of bathrooms was horrific, all blocked and staff didn’t seem to care when I complained about it. Most toilets blocked throughout the whole evening despite receptionist’s promises that maintenance staff was on the way.  However, in contrast one woman said: Great place! The place was amazing, great vibe and very nice architecture. Music not too bad either! Ps. They have drinks for 2€ and free entry before 7pm. And back in 2013 Meghan seemed to be in agreement. Following her trip this week the tweet has resurfaced and fans are loving it. Meghan has since deleted her Twitter account, but a number of replies to the original tweet are still on the social media platform, which seemingly verify it as genuine. One fan said: Can we all take a moment for the fact that the last time Meghan Markle was in Dublin she was slinging €2 drinks in Diceys. Never forget. Will Meghan take Harry back to reminisce with a €2 cocktail? Probably not if their packed agenda is anything to go by.  The trip signals the start of their first overseas trip as a married couple, and the Duchess emerged wearing an outfit by her designer of the moment, Givenchy. Waiting to greet the royal couple today were Britain's Ambassador to Ireland Robin Barnett and his partner Agnieszka Kepka. The newlyweds will get a taste of Irish life and learn more about Ireland's rich history. They will also attend a summer garden party at the British Ambassador Robin Barnett's residence, where they will meet people from across Ireland's arts, sports, military and social enterprise sectors.  Their Royal Highnesses will attend the Gaelic sports festival at the Gaelic Athletic Association's home of Croke Park and head to Trinity College, where they will see the Book of Kells, one of Ireland's greatest cultural treasures - not to mention it's tipped as one of the best things to see and do in Dublin .

story: NewsMum reveals how maternal instinct led to her saving her newborn baby from deadly sepsisAlthough Mirror writer Amanda Killelea admits she had never heard of the life-threatening infection, something inside her told her that baby daughter Lola needed urgent help&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmanda Killelea22:39, 10 JUL 2018Updated02:15, 11 JUL 2018NewsMum Amanda Killelea with lucky Lola at five months and Gracie (Image: Amanda Killelea)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet soaps updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCoronation Street viewers were left in shock when little Jack Webster had to have his foot amputated after contracting sepsis from a grazed knee. Like distraught dad Kevin Webster, I too had never heard of the deadly disease until my daughter Lola developed the condition at just two days old, and our world was turned upside down. I’d had the perfect pregnancy and everything seemed to be going to plan, including going into labour on my due date. The hospital I was supposed to have her at was full, so in a no-room-at-the-inn-style drama, my midwife had to ring round to find a hospital that could take us. We made it to the delivery suite at Fairfield General Hospital in Bury, Greater Manchester with only 30 minutes to spare before Lola arrived into the world – a perfectly healthy 7lb 1oz bundle of joy. But two days later, I knew there was something terribly wrong with my baby.  She was burning up and yelped in pain like a little cat when I picked her up. Worried, I asked one of the doctors to look at her, but he tried to reassure me saying I had probably just over-wrapped her and she had colic. But, as a second-time mum, I knew instinctively he was wrong. My one-year-old, Gracie (now 13) had suffered from colic, and this was different. Lola wasn’t too hot because I had her wrapped up – she definitely had a temperature.  So, when a junior doctor popped into our room, I told her my fears and demanded a second opinion. Thank God I did. She got a more senior doctor to take a look and he immediately ordered a lumbar puncture. I remember asking him if he thought my baby had meningitis , and the horror when he said yes. It was like someone had stabbed me in the heart. They scooped my baby from my arms and took her away for the painful procedure to see what was making her ill. At that age, babies are too young for pain relief. Instead, a nurse drip-fed her sugar water to distract her as a doctor drew fluid from her spinal column to test for infection.  I was alone on the maternity ward, desperately trying to phone my husband while listening to other mums coo over their healthy babies. It was the longest hour of my life. Lola was admitted to the special care baby unit, where doctors pumped her tiny veins with antibiotics and antiviral drugs to fight the infection, while they desperately tried to pinpoint what it was. Some of the drugs were so strong I had to sign consent forms and was warned that they may leave her with permanent hearing problems. But I didn’t care – I wanted them to do whatever it took to save my baby’s life. Test after test came back negative – the doctors couldn’t find out what was making Lola so sick. So they just continued with the drugs, as I spent every waking hour at her bedside. As the veins in her tiny hands gave up, they started using the veins in her feet. When they had used all those, they then wanted to use the veins in her head. I refused, and sat for hours holding the tiny cannula into her foot to deliver the last scraps of antibiotic. When they wanted to put another needle into her stomach to take a urine sample, I held her over a tiny potty for hours until she passed water. I didn’t want my baby to have any more needles put into her unless it was really necessary. Our priest came to the hospital to bless Lola. He offered to christen her there and then in case she didn’t make it but we declined, refusing to believe that our baby would die.

title: prince harry makes cheeky joke
story: NewsPrince Harry makes cheeky joke at dad Charles's expense during trip to Dublin with MeghanThe Duke of Sussex didn't seem to mind he was offending his father in front of dozens of garden party guests&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks22:57, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Harry left guests giggling after making a cheeky jibe at his father Charles during a speech at a garden party in Dublin on Tuesday night. The Duke of Sussex didn't seem to mind that he was offending the heir to the throne as he spoke in front of dozens gathered at Glencairn. Prince Charles recently visited Cork and this week Harry and wife Meghan have embarked on their first official overseas royal engagement as a married couple. They will spend two days following a packed itinerary exploring Ireland's capital. And the pair could not stop smiling as they stepped out hand-in-hand for the evening occasion.   Meghan wore a stunning black sleeveless dress by New Zealand designer Emilia Wickstead, her third outfit of the day. She also swapped her chic bun up-do for loose curls.  She opted for black stiletto pump heels by Aquazzura Deneuve which retail for $750. And to finish the look she held a Givenchy black satin clutch. Before Harry began his speech, the couple sipped on champagne. He started by saying how grateful they were for the warm welcome they had received in Ireland and gushed about his family's love of the country. As well as throwing in a few jokes, the one that got onlookers laughing the most was about Harry's father, Charles.  Harry said: “As some of you may know, he [Irish Prime Minister] showed my father around his home city of Cork just a couple of weeks ago. So we are very grateful for you for joining us here this evening as well. And also very nice to know he didn’t bore you senseless, added Harry which left guests giggling, and will no doubt leave his father smiling as well. Harry followed by saying: “My father was telling us just last week how much he had enjoyed his recent visit and said that each of his visits over the years holds a special place in his memory. “My grandmother the Queen also spoke of her own visit in 2011 and the fantastic welcome that she too received.

title: prince harry wont say footballs
story: NewsPrince Harry won't say football's coming home - because he doesn't want to “jinx” England's chances of winning World CupThe Duke of Sussex was asked by Irish rugby ace Brian O’Driscoll if he thought the Three Lions would win the World Cup - but he remained tight-lipped&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRussell Myers00:12, 11 JUL 2018Updated02:01, 11 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Harry last night said he didn’t want to “jinx” England 's chances of lifting the World Cup - as he chatted to former Irish rugby ace Brian O’Driscoll at a garden reception in Dublin.  The Duke of Sussex, 33, refused to be pushed on the squad’s success. Ace O’Driscoll said: “I asked him ‘so, is football coming home?’ “But he refused to say it. “I think he just said he isn’t as confident as everyone else about England winning tomorrow. “He said he won’t say it because he doesn’t want to jinx it.”   Cheeky Harry also made a dig at the Prince of Wales as he stood on stage with Meghan by his side, while thanking the audience for attending.   Paying tribute to the British Ambassador in Ireland, Robin Barnett, Harry said: “As some as you may know he showed my father around his home city of Cork a couple of weeks ago. “So we are very grateful for you joining us here his evening as well. “And also very nice to know that he didn’t bore you senseless.  He added:“My father was telling us just last week how much he had enjoyed his recent visit. “And that each of his visits over the years hold a special place in his memory.”  Ambassador Barnett followed Harry on stage, and claimed Ireland as nation was rooting for England’s success in today's World Cup game. He thanked the newlyweds for making the trip to Ireland as their first official overseas trip, adding: “We thank you. Perhaps there is romance in our summer air.”  The trip is the latest in a series of foreign visits the royal family have made to EU member states in the wake of Brexit , as part of a “charm offensive” to renew relationships with countries as Britain prepares for Brexit.   Glencairn House is the official residence of the British Ambassador to Ireland and has been the home to successive ambassadors since the 1950s. The house is located in the southern suburbs of Dublin, on the Murphystown Road in the Leopardstown area.

story: NewsQueen struggles to hand over the new colours to RAF because of windy conditionsThe monarch was at a ceremony at Buckingham Palace to mark 100 years since the air force was formed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Burke17:29, 10 JUL 2018Updated17:48, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen found herself in a spot of bother today - when the wind caused havoc as she presented a new honour to RAF chiefs. title: teenage scuba diver discovers huge
story: NewsTeenage scuba diver discovers huge 600kg World War One bomb under Teignmouth PierJames Cunningham, 19, was diving with his uncle off when he swam past what he thought was a huge container under Teignmouth Pier in Devon&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRom Preston-Ellis14:54, 10 JUL 2018Updated15:25, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage scuba diver has discovered a huge World War One bomb found under a seaside resort pier. James Cunningham, 19, was diving with his uncle off the Devon coast when he swam past what he thought was a huge container. After getting closer to the object, James quickly recognised it as something far more dangerous. Both James, from Bishopsteignton, and his uncle swam to the surface and contacted the authorities, reports Devon Live . James said: It was about 5pm yesterday when I was scuba diving off the coast of Teignmouth and came across the device.  I could see it from quite a distance and it was about the same width as my arm span. At first I thought it possibly looked like some sort of container that was covered in rust. Only by looking a bit closer we then discovered that it was in fact a bomb. We swam away post-haste and went back to shore to contact the police. I had taken a bearing so I was able to go back out with the Navy this morning to show them exactly where it was. The whole of the Teignmouth seafront has been evacuated by police with Royal Navy Bomb Disposal vans and coastguard crews at the scene.

title: griffith observatory evacuated after huge
story: NewsGriffith Observatory evacuated after huge brush fire breaks out near popular Los Angeles tourist spotThe tourist spot, overlooking the Hollywood Hills, was evacuated after the fire broke out around 2pm on Tuesday&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBelisa Silva01:46, 11 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A popular tourist attraction near the Hollywood Hills had to be evacuated on Tuesday after a large brush fire broke out.  Huge red flames and smoke could be seen rising near the Griffith Observatory, which overlooks Los Angeles, in California. According to authorities, the blaze, which started around 2pm local time, began near the landmark facility in the the southeastern section of Griffith Park at the edge of the observatory grounds. It quickly spread, burning down more than two acres of chaparral and grass, which were dried out after a gruelling weekend heat wave. Thankfully no injuries were reported.  City fire department spokesman Brian Humphrey reported that the blaze posed no immediate threat to the historic observatory building, which is located on the southern slope of Mount Hollywood, nor to any nearby homes. The fire followed days of dangerously high temperatures which baked Los Angeles and much of the rest of Southern California, causing widespread power outages and contributing to a destructive wildfire in Santa Barbara County.

title: woman gets kinder egg stuck
story: NewsWoman gets Kinder Egg stuck in her vagina after 'romantic' proposal goes horribly wrongA former doctor has shared a shocking true story of a proposal gone horribly wrong, which saw a woman end up in hospital after getting a Kinder Egg stuck inside herself&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin13:53, 10 JUL 2018Updated19:49, 10 JUL 2018News (Image: iStockphoto)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailProposals are kind of a big deal. There's a ring to be bought, lots of planning involved and of course the pre-proposal jitters. Will they say yes? Will they think you've done a good job? There's also a lot that can go wrong. And we're not just talking about rejection. Timing can be messed up, people can interrupt - and as one woman discovered, the ring can get stuck inside you. The story of a woman who wanted to give her boyfriend a 'Kinder Surprise' has been shared in a new book by former junior doctor Adam Kay.   Called This Is Going To Hurt: Confessions Of A Junior Doctor, the book provides a novelisation of Adam's time on the front line for the NHS .  Nestled among the pages is the bizarre story of a proposal gone horribly wrong. The woman, who for obvious reasons remains anonymous, is said to have decided to take advantage of the leap year tradition, that sees women propose to their partners on February 29. For her 'romantic' proposal, she chose to buy an engagement ring, put it inside a Kinder Egg and then insert it into her vagina. The plan was simple - she would suggest some finger-work to her partner, he would discover it, retrieve it and then she would drop down on one knee.  Equal parts unexpected, disgusting and I suppose, romantic, writes Adam. However what the lady hadn't anticipated, was that the Kinder Egg would get stuck. The egg had been inserted vertically but later turned horizontal inside her vagina. No amount of shoogling from either of them would get this particular goose to lay her golden egg, explained Adam. He added: Remarkably, she was so keen to maintain the surprise she wouldn't tell him what she'd done or why.

title: koh tao dad becomes tenth
story: NewsKoh Tao: Dad becomes TENTH Westerner to die mysteriously on Thailand's 'death island' as family fear sinister explanationThai authorities believe 'fit and healthy' Bernd Grotsch, 47, died of “heart failure” or a snake bite - but his family believe there may be something more sinister behind his death&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop11:21, 10 JUL 2018Updated15:20, 10 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad-of-one has become the tenth Westerner to die in mysterious circumstances on Thailand's infamous 'death island'. Bernd Grotsch, 47, was found dead at his home in the heart of the jungle on the notorious island of Koh Tao on June 17. The German had recently returned to the island 'to tie up some loose ends' with his 20-year-old motorbike rental business. His family, who described him as 'fit' and 'healthy', claim authorities told them he died of “heart failure” or had been “bitten by a snake”. But they say they haven't received an autopsy report and believe there is something more sinister behind his death.  The family, from Ingolstadt, Germany, have also complained about his body being sent to the same Bangkok hospital that carried out botched reports on the bodies of Hannah Witheridge and David Miller. The pair were murdered on the same island in 2014. Experts across the world slammed the DNA testing done by the hospital at the time - amid claims it was tampered with in order to scapegoat two Burmese workers currently on death row over the killings. Mr Grotsch's cousin Christina told The Sun the were no explanation for the death of the dad at his home in Mae Haad. She said: He was fit, healthy and happy. We do not trust the authorities in Thailand, especially since there are some oddities.  To date, no autopsy results have been obtained, only vague explanations and conjectures about an alleged deadly bite by a poisonous snake. Or heart and circulatory failure, without further evidence. Christina claimed the family were initially told Mr Grotsch's body had been returned to the mainland in Surat Thani. But when they checked again it was still in a temple on Koh Tao. They allegedly put pressure on the German Embassy in Bangkok, and eventually the body was moved three days later. They family had wanted forensic scientist Dr Pornthip Rojanasunand to perform the autopsy as she is seen worldwide as a respected independent forensic physician, according to the newspaper.  However, his body was instead taken to the Institute of Forensic Medicine, which is where the bodies of Miss Witheridge and Mr Miller were taken. Wealthy entrepreneur Mr Grotsch had moved to the island two decades ago, but left in 2016. He started another business on the island of Koh Phayam, before returning earlier this year to tie up loose ends. He had recently split from wife and Koh Tao native, Oey, with whom he has a seven-year-old daughter, Bene. Mr Grotsch is the tenth known foreigner to die in suspicious circumstances on the 'death island' in just six years. Below, we look at the previous cases. 2012 Brit Ben Harrington , 32, died on the island after his motorbike apparently crashed into an electricity pylon.  His mother Pat Harrington did not accept the explanation by Thai police and has spent years fighting for information from the Thai authorities about her son's death, including submitting Freedom of Information requests to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. Mrs Harrington said she is suspicious of the explanation and had to fight to prevent his body being quickly cremated: [Thai authorities] wanted to cremate Ben the next day, but I screamed and shouted and it was stopped. I had awful problems getting anyone on the phone at first. 2014 Brits Hannah Witheridge and David Miller were murdered as they walked back to their hotel rooms in September 2014. Hannah, 23, from Hemsby, Norfolk, and David Miller, 24, from Jersey, were found dead on Koh Tao on September 15.  Post-mortem examinations showed that the young backpackers, who had met on the island while staying at the same hotel, both suffered head wounds and that Hannah had been raped. Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were sentenced to death for the killings. But although David's family called the verdict 'justice', the trial of the two Burmese migrant workers was plagued by accusations of human rights abuses. Nick Pearson , 25, from Derby, was found floating in the sea on New Year's Day 2014.  His parents believe he was murdered - despite police claims he fell 50ft and drowned. The 25-year-old's mum Tracey told a documentary about the island she would warn parents not to allow their children to travel to the island. 2015 Christina Annesley , 23, died on the island in January 2015 after apparently mixing antibiotics she was taking for a chest infection with alcohol. But the British holidaymaker's parents slammed Thai authorities for failing to investigate the death.  Christina, from Orpington, South East London, died shortly after arriving on Koh Tao. Her dad Boyne said a toxicology report was not carried out. Frenchman Dimitri Povse , 29, was found hanged in a bungalow on the island on New Year's Day 2015 and his death was ruled as suicide despite his hands being tied behind his back. Associate Professor Charnkanit Krittiya Suriyamanee, a criminologist and lecturer at the faculty of social science and humanities of Mahidol University, said he doubted the suicide theory citing some irrelevant evidences, according to Chiangrai Times .  He said that the victim had been drunk to the extent that he was unable to control himself, he would not have been able to tie himself up so tightly that he died of suffocation. He also noted several other odd finds. 2016 Luke Miller, a bricklayer from the Isle of Wight, was found dead in a swimming pool at the Sunset Bar at Sairee Beach on January 8 2016, with an inquest earlier this month finding no evidence he was murdered. He was discovered floating in the water by a member of hotel staff, with his death coming just days after a tragic final Facebook post on New Year's Eve, in which he said: Can honestly say this new year I am living the dream.  Thai police said a post-mortem examination showed he drowned. But, his sister Maria and the family told the BBC they would not rely on what Thai police said as there was still speculation over the circumstances surrounding the death - and that they had received 'different versions' of what might have happened. 2017 Belgian Elise Dallemagne was found dead and half-eaten by lizards having apparently hanged herself on the island - an explanation rejected by her family. The young backpacker had been living at a yoga and tantra retreat, which neighboured the party island of Koh Phangan, in between travelling round Asia, for two years. She was part of the sect of the Sathya Sai Baba cult movement, and lived with a self-proclaimed guru, and left Koh Phangan on April 17 to return home.  Elise then used a fake name of Elise Dubuis to check into the Triple B Bungalows next to Mae Head Pier on Koh Tao as she travelled via the island on a ferry bound for Chumphon province on her route back to capital Bangkok. But an unexplained fire that evening burned down three bamboo huts - including the one Elise had been staying in. Elise fled 2.5km to through the jungle to Tanote Bay and took a room at the Poseidon Resort where she booked another ticket for Bangkok leaving on April 24. Eight days later when locals living near the island's idyllic Tanote Bay became suspicious of a monitor lizard going back and fourth into the jungle they discovered Elise's half-eaten body on May 27 among rocks behind the Tanote Family Bay Resort.

title: prince harry meghan markle ireland
story: NewsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle in Ireland: Politician's faux pas after meeting royal coupleIrish senator Catherine Noone posted on Facebook claiming Meghan Markle had shared her opinion on the abortion referendum result - potentially breaking royal protocol&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCharlotte Neal00:15, 11 JUL 2018Updated02:29, 11 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Irish senator has backtracked on a blunder claiming Meghan Markle broke royal protocol by expressing a political view.  The Duchess of Sussex and husband Prince Harry are in Dublin for their first foreign trip as a married couple.  But just hours into their two-day visit they ran into a spot of bother. Senator Noone's comments were quickly removed and a later tweet simply read: A pleasure to meet Prince Harry &amp the Duchess of Sussex at the British Ambassador's Residence this evening. Posting a screenshot of her first post, Luke Silke tweeted: The Queen will be cross! He added that Prince Harry is in for an almighty dressing down when they go home.
